headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MARTIN, MICHAEL
summary: MARTIN--Michael Townsend, 68, of New York, NY and Longboat Key, FL died April 17, 2010 at home in New York City surrounded by family, after a courageous three year battle with cancer. He was born on November 21, 1941 in New York City to Townsend B. Martin, a founding owner of the New York Jets, and Georgia Shanton who passed away when he was five years old. His stepmother was Irene R. Martin. Michael was the great-grandson of Henry Phipps, a business partner of Andrew Carnegie. The Phipps' family business continues today as Bessemer Trust. He attended Rumson Country Day, Choate, and Rutgers. After serving in the US Navy, Michael became the Assistant General Manager of the NY Jets. While there, the Jets won the Super Bowl in 1969. In 1974, he was named Vice President and Director of Football Operations of the World Football League. At age 34, Michael became the youngest general manager in professional sports when appointed Vice President and general manager of the NY Cosmos of the North American Soccer League. Under his leadership, the Cosmos won NASL crowns in 1977 and 1980. He was a consultant to international sports marketing companies and founded his own business, SportsMark Inc. in 1990. Owner of Michael T. Martin Racing Stable, Michael served on the board of the NY Thoroughbred Horsemen's Association (President, 1994-1997). Michael devoted time and resources to numerous non-profit organizations including Mote Marine Laboratory, The Ringling College of Art and Design, Lemur Conservation Foundation, The Marine Biological Laboratory/Woods Hole, PBS, Phipps Houses, Old Westbury Gardens, The Big Apple Circus, Very Special Arts, NY Special Olympics, Morris Animal Foundation, National Lighthouse Museum, and Juilliard, Choate, and Pennington schools. Michael is survived by Jean Meyer, his wife of thirty years; brother, Alan of Lawrence, KS; son, Ryan and daughter-in-law Maureen, of Butler, PA; son, Christopher of Aurora, IL; stepdaughter, Kathleen Hunt and son-in-law Peter of Chattanooga, TN. Michael, his first wife, Jennifer Johnston Theobald, and Jean were childhood friends. Michael had seven grandchildren, Brandon and Caitlyn Martin, Justin and Margaret Martin, and Mac, Will, and Jack Hunt. The memorial service will be held at St. Bart's Episcopal Church, New York City on Saturday, May 22 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Mote Marine Laboratory, 1600 Ken Thompson Parkway, Sarasota, FL 34236, Ringling College of Art and Design, 2700 No. Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, FL 34234, and Lemur Conservation Foundation, Myakka City Lemur Reserve, P.O. Box 249, Myakka City, FL 34251.

headline: Did Goldman Pay Too High a Price?
summary: Goldman Sachs seems to have uncharacteristically misjudged a market. The security in question is 10-year warrants linked to the government's rescue of banks. The Treasury received what are effectively options to buy stock when it invested in the banks at the nadir of the crisis; now, they are being sold. Having repaid funds from the Troubled Asset Relief Program, some firms are buying back their warrants, too. Goldman paid Treasury's $1.1 billion asking price. Others opted for Treasury to sell them to the highest bidder. Two recent auctions imply that Goldman, for one, overpaid.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths JOSEPH, FREDERICK H.
summary: JOSEPH--Frederick H., of New York City and Andover, MA died on November 27, 2009. Born in Boston, MA in 1937, he was the son of Sara Mostowitz Joseph and the late Edward Morris Joseph. Mr. Joseph received an A.B. from Harvard College in 1959, and subsequently served as an ensign aboard the minesweeper USS Exultant, where he received a letter of commendation for devotion to duty for fighting a fire aboard ship. Upon graduating from Harvard Business School with an M.B.A. in 1963, Mr. Joseph began his career at E.F. Hutton in corporate finance, where he was trained by his friend and mentor John Shad. He joined Shearson Hammill's corporate finance department in 1970, and in 1973, was promoted to Chief Operating Officer. Mr. Joseph joined Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1974 to co-manage the company's corporate finance department, and became Chief Executive Officer in May 1985. Drexel is credited with the commercialization of the high yield bond market, having underwritten more than 1500 issues and raising more than $158 billion from 1978 through 1989. This included many financings of less than $100 million, some of which funded entrepreneurial venture capitalists including Steve Wynn, T. Boone Pickens, and Ted Turner. From January 1994 until May 1998, Mr. Joseph was Chairman of Clovebrook Capital Corp., a boutique investment banking firm. From May 1998 until April 2001, he was a Senior Advisor and Managing Director of ING Barings LLC. Mr. Joseph returned to focus on middle market companies with Morgan Lewis Githens & Ahn, Inc., which was renamed Morgan Joseph & Co. Inc. in October 2002. Morgan Joseph since has developed into a company of more than 140 employees, which has completed more than $29 billion in transactions, including more than 140 M&A transactions and 90 financings. Mr. Joseph was a passionate outdoorsman and hobbyist. Hunting, farming, and horseback riding were an integral part of his life. He traveled through much of the US and Canada on hunting trips, frequently accompanied by friends, sons-in-law and grandchildren. His trophies included a Pope and Young-rated black bear and a Pope and Young rated atypical white-tailed deer. He also participated in numerous Outward Bound and NOLS exploration courses, including one to Africa with his son, Mark, and one to Mexico with his daughter, Tommi Beth, and her husband, Mike. He was often found working in his home blacksmith forge, where he designed and forged his own tools. He is survived by his wife, Linn Anderson of Andover, MA and her son Andrew Prezkop of Washington, DC; his children: Lisa and Bill Schultz of Summit, NJ; Melinda Burke of Brooklyn, NY; Amy and Jon Humphreys of Summit, NJ; Tommi Beth and Mike McHugh of Denver, CO; and Mark and Starry Joseph of Gloucester, MA; and his former wife, Susan Joseph of New Vernon, NJ. He was the beloved grandfather of Billy and Krissy Schultz, Charlotte and Daniel Burke, Molly and Olivia Humphreys and Lucy McHugh. He is also survived by his brother Stephen Joseph and wife Angelique Craney of Chester, CT and New York City; his sister Michelle Joseph Morris and husband Chris of Williamsburg, MA; his mother, Sara Joseph, as well as numerous nieces and nephews. Mr. Joseph was a member of the Board of Directors of several companies, a Trustee of WNET/Channel Thirteen, and a Director of the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation. He also served as Vice Chairman of the Partners of '63, a group of Harvard Business School classmates dedicated to improving public education in this country. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, Dana Farber Cancer Institute or the charity of your choice. Private interment at West Parish Cemetery in Andover MA. A memorial service will be held in New York City for family and friends. For details on the memorial service please call Morgan Joseph & Co. Inc. 212-218-3700.

headline: E.T.F. Access At a Low Cost
summary: Want to build an inexpensive investment portfolio? Now you have access to supercheap building blocks, as well as easy instructions.

headline: Barbie's New Job, Computer Engineer
summary: Barbie has come a long way since 1992, when the blond bombshell of a doll was programmed to say ''Math class is tough.'' Her various careers have taken Barbie from aerobics instructor to supermodel to business executive. Her next will be a computer engineer, an occupation chosen for her by half a million Barbie fans.

headline: John T. Elson, Author of 'Is God Dead?,' Dies at 78
summary: All journalists want to write a story that makes a big splash. John T. Elson, the religion editor at Time magazine, was no exception. But in 1966 he got more than he bargained for. For more than a year, Mr. Elson had labored over an article examining radical new approaches to thinking about God that were gaining currency in seminaries and universities and spilling over to the public at large.

headline: Another Week, Another Westin
summary: The hotel industry may be suffering, but you wouldn't know it by looking at the lineup of new Westin Hotels. The upscale hotel chain plans to open about one hotel a week for the rest of the year. Westin, which is owned by Starwood Hotels & Resorts, is opening six hotels this month and next, including the Westin Washington Dulles Airport and Westin Lake Mary in Orlando, Fla. The remaining four are abroad, including the Westin Pune Koregaon Park, in Pune, India, above.

headline: App of the Week: Google's Eyes on the Ground
summary: GoogleGoggles is a new free app for smartphones using the Android operating system. With its grab bag of features, the app is a bit hard to define. Goggles uses a phone's camera for data entry, Web searching and shopping, with a little bit of augmented reality thrown in. Here's how it works. You use your phone to take a photo of a building, artwork, a bar code or some text and Goggles identifies it and brings back Google search results. A photo of a book cover brought back links to where the book is sold online, reviews, a Wikipedia entry on the author and more. A picture of the exterior of a restaurant brings back reviews, links to the restaurant's Web site and a link to call the place with one click.

headline: Saudi Gets Prison for Selling Phony Goods to the Military
summary: HOUSTON -- A Saudi man was sentenced Thursday to four years in prison for selling counterfeit computer parts to the Marine Corps for use in Iraq and Afghanistan. The sentencing of the Saudi, Ehab Ashoor, 48, who lived in Sugar Land, Tex., was part of a broader federal crackdown on shady businesses that supply shoddy computer goods to the military and federal agencies.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LYNCH, ROBERT
summary: LYNCH--Rev. Robert Gerard, S.J., on October 20, 2009. Beloved brother of John J., Rev. T. Patrick, S.J., Rev. Edward C., S.J., Sister Barbara, CSJ and the late William F. Lynch. Cherished uncle of many nieces, nephews and grandnieces and -nephews. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 E. Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY on Thursday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at Murray-Weigel Hall on Friday at 11:30am. Interment will take place at the Jesuit Martyrs' Shrine, Auriesville, NY. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718)654-0500.

headline: Inside the Times
summary: International PROPOSED MEDIA LAW

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DRUGS, INC. This four-part mini-series on drugs in America begins with an examination of how cocaine is produced and distributed -- from peasant farmers who make cocaine paste to a trafficker linked to Mexican cartels to a dealer in Miami. At 9 the series continues with a look at the stimulant methamphetamine, which is made from a common cold remedy. This episode documents a raid on a suspected meth lab and the physical damages caused by the drug. 10 A.M. (CNN) FAREED ZAKARIA GPS Guests include George Osborne, Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer, on his country's recent fiscal austerity; and Anjem Choudary, who was born in England and is a proponent of radical Islam.

headline: Boy, 16, Is Charged in Wal-Mart Race Bias Case
summary: WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J. -- The authorities in southern New Jersey said Saturday that they had arrested a 16-year-old boy for activating a public-address system at a Wal-Mart store last week and ordering ''all black people'' to leave. The boy, from Atlantic County, was charged by Gloucester County authorities with bias and intimidation and harassment in connection with the episode last Sunday. If convicted, he could face up to a year in a juvenile detention center, officials said. His name was not released because he is a minor.

headline: Now Selling Music Files, Not Sharing
summary: In the music business, they would call it a comeback. Almost a decade ago, Niklas Zennstrom and Janus Friis, European technology entrepreneurs, unleashed the Napster-like file-sharing program Kazaa on the Web, allowing millions of users to freely download songs, movies and TV shows.

headline: Palin the Analyst
summary: Making her debut as a Fox News analyst, former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska immediately picked up the network's mantra on Tuesday night, promising that she would provide ''fair and balanced commentary.'' That seemed to mean largely agreeing with her host, Bill O'Reilly, that President Obama's decline in polls is not a surprise and that Senator Harry Reid and Speaker Nancy Pelosi are out of touch. (''Do you think that she's a kook?'' Mr. O'Reilly asked about Ms. Pelosi.)

headline: YouTube's Entry Into Film Rentals
summary: By the measures of the movie rental market, YouTube's first foray into charging users to stream full-length feature films was hardly a runaway success. YouTube said last month that it would dip its toe into the digital movie rental business with five independent films tied to the Sundance Film Festival. The company said the five films, which were available for 10 days, received a combined 2,684 views.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths LATSHAW, JOHN
summary: LATSHAW--John, 88 known as "Big John", a beloved friend, and father, passed away on July 18, 2010, in Naples, Florida. Born in Kansas City on December 10, 1921 to a prominent family in the area since the early 1800's. His family fortune was wiped out in the Depression and still only a boy; John found five jobs while going to school when most men couldn't find one. As a young man, he started out as a cashier for the securities firm of Harris, Upham. One day, he was asked to fill in for a stock trader who was sick. Though shy, he quickly showed he was a natural born trader "not a charts and research" trader but a visceral trader whose great instinct would benefit many people, for decades to come. In 1954, Big John was a managing partner of Uhlmann & Latshaw, which then merged with EF Hutton & Co. making him the youngest partner in Hutton's history. He rose to become Executive Vice President, managing director, member of the executive committee and director of E.F. Hutton Inc., the E.F. Hutton Group and E.F. Hutton International and his opinions on the economy have been widely quoted, and he was an oft-requested speaker. When most men retire, he did and became the Chairman of the Board, and Chief Executive Officer of B.C. Christopher & Company. Later, he left the brokerage business to become Chief Executive Officer, Chairman and owner of what he named Latshaw Enterprises, Inc., which included Latshaw Tools, Wescon Products Company, Anderson & Forrester, Coast Wire & Plastic Tech, Inc., and MC Electronics, and held positions at numerous other ventures. Civic duty ran in his family and President Harry Truman, who was friends with his uncle, Judge Latshaw, befriended him as a young man so John was always involved in politics not just as a contributor for local, state and national races but by devoting his time for his friends who ran for state office or working on national campaigns such as: running the Re-elect Nixon campaign for Missouri and Kansas for the landslide victory in 1972. Later, he was National Chairman of Democrats for Ford as he was, in fact, a life-long Democrat, which illustrates his independent spirit and preference for people not adherence to rigid ideas and he was a great supporter on both sides of the aisle. He was appointed His Majesties' Royal Thai Consul to the United States by His Majesty the King of Thailand. Years later, in 1983, at Saranrom Palace, Bangkok, Thailand, Mr. Latshaw was decorated by the Prime Minister of Thailand with the Chaturathabhorn of the Most Exalted Order of the White Elephant Award, the highest award given to a civilian, in honor of their contributions to Thailand. A decade later, he was decorated with The Knight Commander of the Most Noble Order of the Crown of Thailand at the Thai Embassy in Washington, D.C. He was also honored and made a Knight Hospitalier of Malta by the Sovereign Order of St. John of Jerusalem. He received the Citation of Merit for Outstanding Achievement and Meritorious Service in Business and Public Administration in 1957, the first year such an award was given by the University of Missouri. On April 30, 1970, in the U.S. Senate, he was given the Golden Eagle Award for "defending the principles of capital formation, achievements in business and civic action, and full dedication of economic freedom in all its broad humanity". His interests were not limited to finances or politics so with his friend, Lamar Hunt, he helped bring the unknown sport of soccer to the United Sates, forming the North American Soccer League and his team, the Kansas City Spurs, won the first championship. He was part of the introduction of cable television to the United States and as chairman, formed a coalition of civic leaders to create the fifth largest cable operation in the United States, American Cablevision. His exceptional dynamism and talent enabled him to serve on an unusual number of organizations and charitable causes among which: the NASA Advisory Board to the President of the United States, 1983-1986; He was member of the Exec. Board of the Religious Heritage of America Executive Board, Invest-in-America A member of the Society of Fellows- the Nelson Gallery of Art; and the Chairman- Board of Trustees the Conservatory of Music. He was truly "larger than life". When asked how tall he was, he would wryly reply "five foot-twenty". Yet it was not due to his stature but because of the kind person he was that everyone called him "Big John". He was a loyal friend, an inspiration to his co-workers, and was a mentor to many. He was an innovative thinker who refused to quit. He loved life and lived by his motto of "making money and having fun - but not one without the other" and made life, frankly, just more fun. A gentleman with a delightful sense of humor, and an impish grin, he always had a twinkle in his eye. In his teens, he could clear the dance floor but even at the end of his life, he could still make women swoon as they fondly recalled, "he was the best dancer". He was well known throughout the world but always proud to be from Kansas City - a city he loved so much and supported, and his adopted home of Naples, Florida. He was preceded in death by his parents, Edna Parker Latshaw and Ross W. Latshaw; his son, Henry John Latshaw III; his brothers, Parker Latshaw, Robert Latshaw, and sister, Mercedes Anderson. He leaves behind his two daughters: Lady Jaffray, Constance, and Elizabeth Albright Latshaw.

headline: Objects Of Desire
summary: Hips are practically vestigial on models, like ngers on whales. Ditto for busts, although implant technology has occasionally produced runway bodies resembling cantaloupes on stilts. But the fall 2010 shows from Marc Jacobs for Louis Vuitton, Prada, Miu Miu andothers were all about the womanly clothes of the 1950s and early '60s. Cleavage spilled.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ARONSON, HERBERT R
summary: ARONSON--Herbert R. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House wish to express our sincere sympathy of the sudden passing of our friend, donor and advisor, Herb Aronson. While our loss of this remarkable man is deep and profound, we cannot imagine the loss to his wife, Connie and the entire Aronson family. We can only be grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of counting him as part of our family and the love and care he offered so freely to those he touched in life! Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan, President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc.

headline: In New Jersey, a Civics Lesson in the Internet Age
summary: It was a silent call to arms: an easy-to-overlook message urging New Jersey students to take a stand against the budget cuts that threaten class sizes and choices as well as after-school activities. But some 18,000 students accepted the invitation posted last month on Facebook, the social media site better known for publicizing parties and sporting events. And on Tuesday many of them -- and many others -- walked out of class in one of the largest grass-roots demonstrations to hit New Jersey in years. The protest disrupted classroom routines and standardized testing in some of the state's biggest and best-known school districts, offering a real-life civics lesson that unfolded on lawns, sidewalks, parking lots and football fields.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 7 P.M. (HBO) TELL THEM ANYTHING YOU WANT: A PORTRAIT OF MAURICE SENDAK In 1964 Mr. Sendak's ''Where the Wild Things Are'' won the Caldecott Medal for the most distinguished picture book of the year -- and almost overnight became a bedtime classic. On Friday the filmmaker Spike Jonze (''Being John Malkovich'') will bring the book's wolf-suited protagonist, Max, and its fearsome menagerie to the big screen. In this documentary from Mr. Jonze and Lance Bangs, filmed at Mr. Sendak's Connecticut home and studio beginning in 2003, the writer and illustrator, above, now 81, muses on the things that inspired his creations, from his difficult relationship with his parents and his bond with his older siblings, to his fascination with death. He also reveals his philosophy about communicating with children. ''Tell them anything you want,'' he says. ''If it's true, you tell them.'' The film features photographs from Mr. Sendak's early childhood and excerpts from his sometimes controversial works, including ''In the Night Kitchen,'' which features drawings of a naked boy and was No. 25 on the American Library Association's list of the 100 most frequently challenged books from 1990 to 2000. 8 P.M. (13); 9:30 P.M. (49) JOAN BAEZ: HOW SWEET THE SOUND Ms. Baez made her debut at the Newport Folk Festival in 1959; on Aug. 2 she returned to celebrate its 50th anniversary. Filmed during her recent world tour, this ''American Masters'' documentary chronicles the private life and public career of Ms. Baez, who came to symbolize the social movement of the 1960s. The program includes her reunion with Vaclav Havel in Slovakia and a collaboration with Steve Earle in Nashville, while Bob Dylan, David Crosby, Roger McGuinn, Bonnie Raitt, Jackson Browne and the Rev. Jesse Jackson weigh in.

headline: Overseeing Apple Prototypes
summary: Apple has hired Richard DeVaul, a veteran of the wearable computing field and co-founder of Aware Technologies, a company focused on creating fitness and health products. According to Computerworld, Mr. DeVaul will be a senior prototype scientist at Apple. According to Mr. DeVaul's LinkedIn page, he received a Ph.D. in media arts and sciences from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. While there, he worked on a project called ''The Memory Glasses,'' which offered real-time memory support that could ''improve your performance on a memory recall task by a factor of about 63 percent without distracting you.''

headline: Fox Business Network To Simulcast Imus Show
summary: Broadening its definition of business news, the Fox Business Network said Thursday that it would simulcast the ''Imus in the Morning'' radio show starting on Oct. 5. As expected, Fox said it had signed a multiyear deal with Don Imus, right, the host who was fired by CBS Radio and MSNBC two years ago after making racial remarks about the Rutgers University women's basketball team. His program was revived by the radio company Citadel and the rural television network RFD-TV, but Mr. Imus ended the television deal last month. The simulcast, to be shown from 6 to 9 a.m. Eastern time, is expected to buoy the low-rated Fox Business Network, which began in October 2007. Mr. Imus doesn't make financial news a regular part of his talk show, but Fox said the program ''will incorporate additional business news into its format.'' Notably, three of the anchors partially displaced by Mr. Imus's hiring will host a three-hour morning-news program on the network's Web site, FoxBusiness.com, from 6 to 9. The anchors of the Web show, Jenna Lee, Connell McShane and Ashley Webster, will also appear regularly on ''Imus in the Morning,'' Fox said. Alexis Glick, a vice president at Fox Business who now leads the network's 7 to 10 a.m. hours, will remain the host of the 9 a.m. hour. In a statement, Mr. Imus said: ''I love Fox. Roger Ailes is the pre-eminent genius of American broadcasting. Who wouldn't want to do this?''

headline: The Chatter
summary: '' The big takeaway is, don't mess with the privacy stuff for a long time.'' Mark Zuckerberg, chief executive of Facebook. After an outcry from users over privacy settings, Facebook unveiled controls aimed at helping people better understand what they are sharing online, and with whom. '' It is the single most important turnaround that I have seen in Silicon Valley.'' Jim Breyer, a venture capitalist who has invested in some of the most successful technology businesses, after Apple became the world's most valuable tech company.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GRAY, EDWARD W
summary: GRAY--Edward W. T. The Board of Directors, Volunteers and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. acknowledge with deepest sympathy the passing of benefactor and friend, Edward W. T. Gray III, President of Analytic Asset Management, Inc. and Chairman, The Countess Moira Charitable Foundation. We extend our condolence to his wife, Michele, and the entire Gray family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths DESMEDT, A
summary: DeSMEDT--A. Theodore. On February 5, 2010 A. Theodore (Ted) DeSmedt was called home. Born in the Bronx, New York on April 29, 1917, he was the son of Belgian emigres Albert and Mary DeSmedt. In 1940 he married Eleanor Schneier and soon thereafter went into service for his country as a navigator in the Army Air Force. On December 30th, 1943 their B-24 nicknamed "Sad Sack" was shot down by German fighter planes on the outskirts of Paris. Ted would spend the remainder of the war as a POW in Luftstalag One on the Baltic Sea. Released by the advancing Russian Army he came home and resumed his work with the United States Shipping Lines in the scheduling department. Ted then moved to the Isbrandsten Company and over the years held a number of positions eventually becoming President of the merged American Export Isbrandsten Lines. His career would take him to chief executive positions in the shipping world at States Marine Isthmian, Prudential Grace, Marchessini and Reefer Express Lines. Ted was invited to participate in the renowned Harvard Amp Business School in 1969 along with other corporate executives. He was elected class President. Outside of work, Ted found time to enjoy many other activities. He loved the opera and became the first corporate sponsor of The Metropolitan Opera House. A member of the Downtown Athletic Club, he swam for an hour each day prior to going to the office. He was an Elder in the Upper Saddle River Dutch Reformed Church. He traveled internationally on business and had friends and associates throughout the world. He was equally comfortable in the company of princes, ministers, business executives and longshoremen. In 1982 Ted retired and started a ship chartering and brokerage firm, Shipping Services Company, Inc. in San Mateo, California. Eleanor, his beloved wife of 48 years, passed away in 1988. In 1990 he married Nancy Conway Holland of San Mateo. She was his loving companion for the remainder of his life. His friends and family will always remember him for his calm demeanor and his sage advice. There never was a problem so large or so small that he couldn't help you to work through it. His wisdom will be missed by everyone who had the good fortune to know him as a father, friend, or mentor. Ted is survived by his wife Nancy, his sons Bill (Kathrin), Bob (Dale), four grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, five stepsons, Michael, Patrick, Stephen, Dan, and Kevin and their families.

headline: Odd Brush With Notoriety
summary: We've all been there. Fresh out of the dentist office after a little procedure that leaves us numb in the jaw or tipsy from laughing gas, or both. But most of us didn't have our parents there to capture it on video as David DeVore did. You may recall David, who is now 9, from a 2009 YouTube video that showed him in an anesthesia-induced haze, his head bobbing, asking his father ''Is this real life?'' and at one point, screaming at the top of his lungs. It didn't take long for David to become viral-video famous, with 65 million views. There has to be a way to capitalize on that, right?

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ARONSON, HERBERT
summary: ARONSON--Herbert R. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House wish to express our sincere sympathy of the sudden passing of our friend, donor and advisor, Herb Aronson. While our loss of this remarkable man is deep and profound, we cannot imagine the loss to his wife, Connie and the entire Aronson family. We can only be grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of counting him as part of our family and the love and care he offered so freely to those he touched in life! Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan, President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc.

headline: Neon Signs
summary: With summer quickly approaching, and our moods brightening at the thought of fun in the sun, I gathered some pictures of clothing and accessories reminiscent of those hazy days of the '80s when neon was king. I may not be wearing oversized tees by Body Map or bright rubber bangles; but these current reminders of the time when Spicoli ruled are a different story. I'm feeling (once again) for neon! This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: REUTERS BREAKINGVIEWS
summary: A U.S. Analogy For a Greek Fix

headline: BITS
summary: Yahoo Birthday With Carol Bartz As part of its 15th birthday celebrations, Yahoo last week invited a group of reporters to a lunch with Carol Bartz, the company's chief executive. There were no party hats, but there were cupcakes, and plenty of questions for Ms. Bartz.

headline: Netflix's Deal With Warner
summary: Last week, Netflix cut a deal with Warner Brothers that will delay the availability of new Warner movies to Netflix subscribers by almost a month but expand the number of older Warner films available for digital streaming. Whether this is good for Netflix subscribers depends entirely on how they use the service.

headline: A Google App in Time for Bike-to-Work Week
summary: Just in time for Bike-to-Work Week, May 17 to 21, Google has added bicycling directions to its Maps application. The app allows you to get navigation for bikes in a couple of different ways.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WILLIAMS, SAMUEL DUNSTAN
summary: WILLIAMS--Samuel Dunstan, 73, died Friday, June 18 after a six month battle with cancer. He was the devoted husband of Susan, and the adoring father of their autistic son Edward. He is also survived by two brothers Thomas of Inverness, CA and Resolvert Waldron Williams of Martha's Vineyard, MA, a nephew and many cousins. Sam grew up in Lawrence, Long Island. He was a long time New Yorker. He attended Lawrence Country Day School, graduated from Groton School '55, where he was a member of the crew and captain of the soccer team, and served as the class agent until his death. He also graduated from Harvard '59, where he was a member of the Freshman Crew and was the President of the Phoenix S.K. Club. He served in the U.S. Army as a member of the National Security Agency. Before beginning his long career in the investment business he worked at his family's company, the I.T. Williams Company, which imported hardwoods from the world over. At the time of his death he was a Senior Managing Director of Carret Asset Management, LLC. In the 1980's he was the Chair of the Building Capital Committee to finish the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York. Sam was a member of The Brook, and since 1966 of The Union Club where he served as a governor from 1971 to 1979. He also served on various committees including the Committee on Candidates of which he was Chair from 1976 to 1979, the House Committee, the Finance Committee, the Art Committee and the Entertainment Committee. He was also a member of The Pilgrims. He was a member of the Saint Nicholas Society of the City of New York for 40 years, and served as President from 2001 to 2004. On Long Island he was a long standing member of the Rockaway Hunting Club, the Lawrence Beach Club and the Cedarhurst Yacht Club. He was a member of The Mill Reef Club in Antigua. He served as the President of the Board of his cooperative apartment building from 2003 to 2010. He also served on the Board of AHRC / NYC Foundation, Inc. since it's inception in 1996. He was an ardent advocate for individuals with developmental disabilities because of his son, Edward. He was an avid sportsman who loved the ocean, sailing, deep powder skiing, squash and tennis. He was a brilliant, sensitive, consummate and elegant gentleman with extraordinary charm, poise and a great smile. He will be missed by many. In lieu of flowers, the family requests contributions in Sam's memory to The Saint Nicholas Society of the City of NY, 20 West 44th Street, Room 508, New York, NY 10036-6603 or to The Cedarhurst Yacht Club, c/o NMB Books, Inc., PO Box 631, Pomona, NY 10970. A memorial service will be held in September.

headline: A Genentech Eye Treatment Is Found to Help Prevent Vision Loss in Diabetics
summary: The drug Lucentis can improve eyesight being lost to diabetes, researchers reported on Tuesday, a finding they hailed as a major advance in combating a common cause of blindness. The finding comes from a large government-sponsored clinical trial that tested the drug, which is made by Genentech, as a treatment for the condition known as diabetic macular edema.

headline: Burberry Breeds a Rose
summary: Christopher Bailey's accolades at Burberry are enough to make him blush - in five shades, to be precise. The designer's latest project, Burberry Beauty, is a comprehensive collection of foundations, powders, bronzers, lipsticks and eye shadows that were inspired by the label's classic trench coat and by the moody hues of the British climate. Two years in the making, the line pays homage to Mr. Bailey's vision of a modern English rose. ''The Burberry girl wears just a trace of makeup - no crazy eyes or crazy lips,'' he says. ''Makeup should enhance women, not just cover up what they perceive as flaws.'' Of the sexy reflective checked packaging, he adds, ''The idea was for the products to look and feel like things you really want to have in your bag.'' The range will be available on Nordstrom.com starting Monday and on Burberry.com starting Friday. On the eve of the launch of Burberry Beauty, we asked Mr. Bailey to tell us about his six favorite British beauties. Click on the slide show above to view.

headline: Anger in Europe Over Google and Privacy
summary: BERLIN -- European privacy regulators and advocates reacted angrily Saturday to the disclosure by Google, the world's largest search engine, that it had systematically collected private data since 2006 while compiling its Street View photo archive. After being pressed by European officials about the kind of data the company compiled in creating the archive -- and what it did with that information -- Google acknowledged on Friday that it had collected snippets of private data around the world. In a blog post on its Web site, the company said information had been recorded as it was sent over unencrypted residential wireless networks as Google's Street View cars with mounted recording equipment passed by.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths HARRIS, VIVIAN S.
summary: HARRIS--Vivian S. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House wish to express our sincere sympathy of the passing of our friend, advisor, co-founder of Ronald McDonald House New York, Vivian S. Harris. While our loss of this remarkable woman is deep and profound, we cannot imagine the loss to her daughter, Ellyn Harris and son, Jerry Harris. Vivian Harris served as President of the Board of Directors for her twenty-six years. In 1978, she helped form the foundation of Ronald McDonald House in New York City, creating our organization first known as The Childrens Oncology Society of New York, Inc. Through many obstacles and with great perseverance, Vivian expanded our services in 1993 when she built the largest Ronald McDonald House in the world with the support of The Tri-State McDonald's Owners/ Operators. In recognition of her many years of invaluable and outstanding service Vivian Harris was named President Emeritus. The organization further recognized her distinguished legacy in 2008 when she was awarded the Hope Award, the highest recognition our charity can bestow its volunteers, and established the Vivian Harris Society to honor her triumphant spirit. We are grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of counting Vivian Harris as part of our family and love and care she offered so freely to those she touched in life! Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WATSON, S.J. REV. JOSEPH T.
summary: WATSON--S.J. Rev. Joseph T.,on September 22, 2009. Beloved brother of Sister Joseph Mary Watson, O.P. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Road, Bronx, NY on Thursday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Friday, 11:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Martyrs' Shrine Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718)654-0500.

headline: Radio Streams Through Windows
summary: Q.Can I play Internet radio through Windows Media Player instead of through the Web browser? A. Recent versions of Windows Media Player let you listen to live streaming radio in a few different ways. You can add a stream you find yourself on a radio station's Web site or select one from the collection offered in the Media Guide menu in Windows Media Player. Some sites that collect radio streams from around the world also give you an option to listen to the audio feed through media software like Windows Media Player, iTunes and WinAMP.

headline: A Tough Critic Weighs In
summary: How did the television commentariat react to President Obama's prime-time address on health care? Bill O'Reilly, for one, thought it should have been shorter. ''Way too long,'' actually, is how Mr. O'Reilly put it. And his verdict matters, at least to the five million viewers who watched his Fox News Channel program on Wednesday night. His nightly audience, averaging three million, makes him the most-watched host on cable news.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SWINSKY, MORTON
summary: SWINSKY--Morton. Pioneering bond trader, art collector and multiple Tony Award-winning Broadway producer - died June 19, of prostate cancer. He was 75. Swinsky produced numerous plays and musicals, beginning with 'Eubie' and including hits such as 'Spamalot,' 'Spring Awakening,' David Mamet's 'Race,' 'Guys and Dolls' (Tony), 'Chicago' (Tony), 'Annie Get Your Gun' (Tony),'The Music Man,' 'The Who's Tommy,' 'Hamlet,' 'How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,' 'Grey Gardens,' 'Jersey Boys' (Tony), 'A View From the Bridge,' 'Hairspray' (Tony), 'The History Boys,' 'Billy Elliot' (Tony) and, most recently, 'Fela!,' and 'The Addams Family.' Swinsky was the recipient of film and television awards (AFI, Emmy) for 'You Can Count On Me,' 'Boys Don't Cry' and the concert version of 'Sweeney Todd.' With all these successes, Mort seemed devoid of ego and hubris. Backing a quality play or musical is what brought him pleasure. That and collecting art. Recognized by The National Sculpture Society, Swinsky was a patron to artists mostly in the Figurative Arts. Born to immigrant parents of Russian Jewish descent, Swinsky was raised in the Inwood section of Manhattan. While at City College night school, where he met his wife Florence Swinsky (Pincus), he pursued a job with CJ Devine and Co., where his mind, memory, and ability to predict value propelled him to the top of his field. When Merrill Lynch consolidated operations with CJ Devine, the "Devine Boys" created a high percentage of Merrill's revenue, and were granted the autonomy to run Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc., with Swinsky as Executive Vice President. As a leader and pioneer in the trading of government bonds, Swinsky and his team left in 1980 to join William E. Pollock & Co and in 1990, the "Udder Guys" joined Fuji Securities. He retired from that firm as President. It was during his successful tenure on Wall Street that his eye for talent brought him into the world of Broadway and other arts. Mort touched so many people in his lifetime. He will be remembered and missed. He is survived by Florence, their two daughters Karen and Dana, and five grandchildren, Nikola, Dante and Thanos Carouso and Connor and Harry Cantelmo. A Memorial will be held Monday, July 26 at the Lotos Club, 5 East 66 St, 6:30 -8:30. Additional remembrances can be shared at legacy.com. Contributions in Mort's memory may be made to The National Sculpture Society, and The New York Theater Workshop.

headline: A Recall Years In the Making
summary: CONSUMER advocates say the Dorel Juvenile Group's recall of four million child car seats comes so late it does not matter anymore. Many of the children who once used those seats could have driver's licenses by now, because Dorel and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration fought over the recall for almost a decade. What's more, the seats were so old that Dorel and other safety experts recommended that they no longer be used -- even if the new, safer anchoring straps the safety agency had demanded were installed.

headline: Optimism Takes Charge at an Electronics Show
summary: The mood at last week's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas was decidedly more upbeat than at the previous year's show. At that exhibition, the chatter on the floor was less about innovation and breakthrough technologies than about how to weather the economic storm that would impede the kind of discretionary spending much of the electronics industry relies on. This year's show was a return to optimism. Tablet-size reading devices and three-dimensional television were two technologies often mentioned when exhibitors talked about future prosperity, but there were also developments in the comparatively mature industries of personal computing and cellphones.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Massey, Paul
summary: MASSEY--Paul, Sr. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of the Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. acknowledge with deepest sympathy the passing of Paul Massey, Sr., loving father of our friend and supporter, Paul J. Massey, Jr. Condolences are extended to his entire family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc.

headline: To Win, Beat the Apps
summary: Video game makers are expecting a brutal holiday season, and it has nothing to do with their violent new games. The behemoths of the industry -- Nintendo, Sony and Microsoft -- as well as the industry's top developers are girding for fierce competition in what they all expect to be the second revenue-impaired holiday season in a row.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GIFFUNI, ALICE QUADRE
summary: GIFFUNI--Alice Quadre, 92. Died peacefully in New York City on April 1, 2010, with her children by her side. Widow of Andrew L. Giffuni, she was the proud mother of Vincent Q. Giffuni (Mary Ann) and Nini G. Tiernan (Bart); grandmother of Matthew Q. Giffuni, Sara G. Joseph (Rob), Olivia A. Tiernan and Julia T. Weidinger (Jack); and great-grandmother of Wade and Emily Joseph and Hugh Weidinger V. A graduate of James Madison High School in Brooklyn, she went on to study Romance Languages at Mount Holyoke College, finishing as a Phi Beta Kappa. She worked as an interpreter for the Argentine government until she married. Her greatest pleasures were sewing, knitting and reading. She enjoyed going to the opera, theatre, museums and the movies. Most of all, she loved to travel and did so most of her life, bringing home fabrics and plant cuttings wherever she could. She was called "D'Alice" by those closest to her, short for "Grand Alice". And that she was. A true lady, ahead of her time. Smart, interesting and interested as well. She looked great to the end, never showing her age. The pearl lady. May she rest in peace. A gathering of family and friends to celebrate the life of D'Alice will be held on Friday, April 16 from 5-7pm at 114 East 72nd Street. Donations in her honor to The Macula Foundation, Inc. at 210 East 64th Street, New York, NY 10065, would be deeply appreciated.

headline: Cyberattack Threat on Rise, Executives Say
summary: A study based on responses from 600 computing and computer-security executives in 14 countries suggests attacks on the Internet pose a growing threat to the energy and communication systems that underlie modern society. The findings, issued Thursday by the Center for Strategic and International Studies and the computer-security company McAfee, echoed alarms raised this month by Google after it experienced a wave of cyberattacks.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths JOFFE, ROBERT D.
summary: JOFFE--Robert D. Time Warner Inc. mourns the passing of our longtime trusted advisor, confidant and friend Bob Joffe. Saying that Bob was a brilliant lawyer doesn't do justice to the magnitude of his gift or depth of his influence on our company. He was a problem-solver of the highest order. Over Bob's more than 35 years as our outside counsel, a succession of Time Warner leaders relied on his impeccable judgment in the most complex and sensitive situations. He was not only widely respected for his wisdom and conviction, but also revered for his decency and humanity. He will be greatly missed. We extend our deepest sympathies to Bob's wife, Dinny, and his entire family. Jeff Bewkes and the Time Warner family

headline: Google Buys Digitizing Service
summary: Acknowledging once again that humans are better than computer algorithms at some tasks, Google said on Wednesday that it had acquired ReCaptcha, a start-up that grew out of a research project at Carnegie Mellon, for an undisclosed amount. Captchas are those strange word puzzles that Web sites use to distinguish humans from automated spamming software and other nasty ''bots.'' ReCaptcha, founded by the inventor of the captcha, the computer scientist Luis von Ahn, puts this test to practical use, taking words from decaying old newspapers and other texts that computers can't read and letting people identify them, thus proving that they are people.

headline: Nike Denies Signing Vick To an Endorsement Deal
summary: In a signal that Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Michael Vick still has a long way to go before attracting major endorsements, Nike on Thursday clarified reports that it had signed a contract with him, even as it acknowledged that it had agreed to give him free products. ''Nike does not have a contractual relationship with Michael Vick,'' KeJuan Wilkins, a Nike spokesman, said in a statement. ''We have agreed to supply product to Michael Vick as we do a number of athletes who are not under contract with Nike.''

headline: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.
summary: A NEW TUNNEL, But Not for Trains

headline: Dial-Surfing on a Cellphone
summary: The next generation of radio listeners might not remember the olden days of scrolling through stations by turning a knob on a car or home stereo. Instead, the radio they listen to could very well be on their mobile phones. Pandora, which runs a popular streaming radio Web site, on Wednesday released its application for phones running the Android software from Google. It's available for download in the Android Market. Pandora is available on the iPhone, BlackBerry and Palm Pre. Of the 65,000 people who register for a Pandora account each day, 45,000 do so on mobile phones, said Tim Westergren, above, Pandora's founder. ''I'm beginning to think that our future is going to be more mobile-centric than I had even thought, and sooner,'' he said.

Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths FRIEDMAN, JACK JULY 9
summary: FRIEDMAN--Jack July 9, 1939 May 3, 2010. Toy Pioneer Jack Friedman, who made his mark over his 50 year career with some of the most iconic playthings of our time, has died at the age of 70. Friedman, of Thousand Oaks, CA and originally from Queens, NY, was founder and Chairman for leading toymaker JAKKS Pacific, and founder of video game company THQ, Inc. Friedman launched some of the most successful toys in history, including the first movie toys for E.T.: The Extra-Terrestrial, Michael Jackson dolls, wrestling action figures, Pac-Man plug it in and play TV Games and an array of innovative products for millions of children. Friedman died on Monday, May 3, 2010 from complications caused by a rare blood disease. He is survived by his wife Karen Friedman, and his children Brooke Porter and her husband Tom, and Tony Friedman, and his step children Shannon and Andrew Farrell. JAKKS CEO Stephen Berman said, "Jack was a legendary toymaker and a real titan in our industry. He dedicated his talents to JAKKS Pacific for 15 years, and he will be sorely missed." JAKKS Board of Directors said, "We are greatly saddened by the passing of Jack Friedman. He was a visionary leader who guided the Company with wisdom and keen judgment. Toys were his passion, and his legacy will live on in JAKKS Pacific." Friedman founded JAKKS Pacific in January 1995, and he served as its Chairman and Chief Executive Officer through March 31, 2010. Under his leadership, JAKKS has grown into a Top 5 US publicly traded diversified toy company. Before JAKKS, he led LJN Toys until its sale to MCA in 1985, and then went on to form THQ, Inc. in 1989 and led it until 1995. Friedman was a generous philanthropist and supporter of the Company's JAKKS Cares program, which has benefited organizations such as The Toy Industry Foundation, Camp Ronald McDonald for Good Times, The Special Olympics, Feed the Children, Boys & Girls Clubs of America, Marine Toys for Tots and more. Under the program, the Company has donated over $40 million worth of toys and school supplies to children around the world. Friedman was a proud yo-yo champion and avid golfer, and recently retired from his regular duties at JAKKS Pacific to spend more time with his family. The funeral will be held at the Forest Lawn South Mortuary in Davie Florida on Friday, May 7th and there will be a Memorial Service at the Malibu Jewish Center on Thursday, May 13th. In lieu of flowers, donations in the name of Jack Friedman can be made to one of the following organizations: The Toy Industry Foundation (TIF) - donations.toyindustryfoundation.org or research under the direction of Dr. Gary Schiller at UCLA's Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Center - www.cancer.ucla.edu/giving

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths HARRIS, VIVIAN S
summary: HARRIS--Vivian S. The Board of Directors, Volunteers, and Staff of the Ronald McDonald House wish to express our sincere sympathy of the passing of our friend, advisor, co-founder of Ronald McDonald House New York, Vivian S. Harris. While our loss of this remarkable woman is deep and profound, we cannot imagine the loss to her daughter, Ellyn Harris and son, Jerry Harris. Vivian Harris served as President of the Board of Directors for her twenty-six years. In 1978, she helped form the foundation of Ronald McDonald House in New York City, creating our organization first known as The Childrens Oncology Society of New York, Inc. Through many obstacles and with great perseverance, Vivian expanded our services in 1993 when she built the largest Ronald McDonald House in the world with the support of The Tri-State McDonald's Owners/ Operators. In recognition of her many years of invaluable and outstanding service Vivian Harris was named President Emeritus. The organization further recognized her distinguished legacy in 2008 when she was awarded the Hope Award, the highest recognition our charity can bestow its volunteers, and established the Vivian Harris Society to honor her triumphant spirit. We are grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of counting Vivian Harris as part of our family and love and care she offered so freely to those she touched in life! Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

headline: Streamlined Chucks
summary: TERENCE KOH, an artist known as much for his extraordinary wardrobe (monkey-fur coats, metal Balenciaga leggings) as his work, has lately turned his attention to fashion. Following a T-shirt collaboration with Opening Ceremony last summer, Mr. Koh (above) has now designed white leather Converse sneakers, stripped down and smoothed out for a minimalist effect. ''I wanted to design the simplest Converse shoe possible,'' he explained. ''I see it as a perfect round white pearl.'' And it is just the start of his design career: ''I want to do more things in fashion,'' Mr. Koh said, adding that he was in discussions for a fragrance. ''Fashion is more interesting than art.''

headline: Far-Ranging Support for Google's Rebuff to China
summary: Google's surprising decision this week to abandon cooperation with Chinese government censors -- and, possibly, its four-year effort to do business here -- is galvanizing an unusually broad coalition of foreigners who hope for a fresh chance to rein in the conduct of an emerging great power. Most of those forces -- from the American right and left, the business and technology communities and human-rights advocacy groups -- are united by a belief that their concerns over China's human-rights and free-speech constraints have been buried in a rush to online profit.

headline: Be Wary of the Rush to Gold
summary: Most of us have seen advertisements to buy gold or offering cash for gold. With the economy still unsettled and gold prices steadily rising, you may be tempted. But not all gold investments are safe.

headline: Europe Lets Google Sell Brand Advertising
summary: PARIS -- The European Union's highest court on Tuesday gave Google broad latitude to sell advertising spots to rivals of trademarked brands when users do searches for names like Louis Vuitton. But it also said that the search engine might have to do more to protect brand owners from infringements. In a case brought by the luxury goods company LVMH Moët Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the European Court of Justice said Google should not be required to block sales of brand names as advertising keywords. However, the judges said advertisers, or Google, could be liable for trademark violations in individual cases.

headline: NASA Tests Engine With an Uncertain Future
summary: One hundred fifty-four feet long, packed with 700 tons of propellant and anchored to the side of a Utah hill, a solid rocket motor developed for NASA's next generation of rockets is to unleash 3.6 million pounds of thrust in a test Tuesday morning. Whether this motor design will ever go anywhere is uncertain.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths Watson, Joseph T.
summary: WATSON--S.J. Rev. Joseph T., on September 22, 2009. Beloved brother of Sister Joseph Mary Watson, O.P. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray-Weigel Hall, 515 E. Fordham Road, Bronx, NY on Thursday from 3-5 and 7-9pm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, Friday, 11:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Martyrs' Shrine Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718)654-0500.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths MARTIN, MICHAEL TOWNSEND
summary: MARTIN--Michael Townsend, 68, of New York, NY and Longboat Key, FL died April 17, 2010 at home in New York City surrounded by family, after a courageous three year battle with cancer. He was born on November 21, 1941 in New York City to Townsend B. Martin, a founding owner of the New York Jets, and Georgia Shanton who passed away when he was five years old. His stepmother was Irene R. Martin. Michael was the great-grandson of Henry Phipps, a business partner of Andrew Carnegie. The Phipps' family business continues today as Bessemer Trust. He attended Rumson Country Day, Choate, and Rutgers. After serving in the US Navy, Michael became the Assistant General Manager of the NY Jets. While there, the Jets won the Super Bowl in 1969. In 1974, he was named Vice President and Director of Football Operations of the World Football League. At age 34, Michael became the youngest general manager in professional sports when appointed Vice President and general manager of the NY Cosmos of the North American Soccer League. Under his leadership, the Cosmos won NASL crowns in 1977 and 1980. He was a consultant to international sports marketing companies and founded his own business, SportsMark Inc. in 1990. Owner of Michael T. Martin Racing Stable, Michael served on the board of the NY Thoroughbred Horsemen's Association (President, 1994-1997). Michael devoted time and resources to numerous non-profit organizations including Mote Marine Laboratory, The Ringling College of Art and Design, Lemur Conservation Foundation, The Marine Biological Laboratory/Woods Hole, PBS, Phipps Houses, Old Westbury Gardens, The Big Apple Circus, Very Special Arts, NY Special Olympics, Morris Animal Foundation, National Lighthouse Museum, and Juilliard, Choate, and Pennington schools. Michael is survived by Jean Meyer, his wife of thirty years; brother, Alan of Lawrence, KS; son, Ryan and daughter-in-law Maureen, of Butler, PA; son, Christopher of Aurora, IL; stepdaughter, Kathleen Hunt and son-in-law Peter of Chattanooga, TN. Michael, his first wife, Jennifer Johnston Theobald, and Jean were childhood friends. Michael had seven grandchildren, Brandon and Caitlyn Martin, Justin and Margaret Martin, and Mac, Will, and Jack Hunt. The memorial service will be held at St. Bart's Episcopal Church, New York City on Saturday, May 22 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Mote Marine Laboratory, 1600 Ken Thompson Parkway, Sarasota, FL 34236, Ringling College of Art and Design, 2700 No. Tamiami Trail, Sarasota, FL 34234, and Lemur Conservation Foundation, Myakka City Lemur Reserve, P.O. Box 249, Myakka City, FL 34251.

headline: Can Citigroup Carry Its Own Weight?
summary: OVER the past 80 years, the United States government has engineered not one, not two, not three, but at least four rescues of the institution now known as Citigroup. In previous instances, the bank came back from the crisis and prospered. Will Citigroup rise again from its recent near-death experience?

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths SMITH, RUTH
summary: SMITH--Ruth Proskauer. The Governing Council and Members of Quest, the CCNY/CWE Community for Lifelong Learning of the City University of New York notes with deepest sorrow the passing of one of our beloved founders and most active members. Ruth brought vitality to our peer-learning organization that is cherished by all who knew her. Ruth was active in many daily classes and was a coordinator responsible for the Supreme Court Course for many years. We will miss her strong voice and well formed opinions which always enriched our discussions. When asked in an interview in 2008 why she devoted so much time and effort to Quest she answered "...it's so positive, I guess you can tell by the number of years I have been coming. I don't think I would be myself without it, not having a focus for what you are going to do each day, means that you're sort of a couch potato." We at Quest, (www.questonline.org) wish to convey our sincerest condolences to her family, friends and all who were touched by her tireless efforts on behalf of Women's Rights and her advocacy for the rights of the terminally ill. Marc W. Deitch, MD, President Quest: Community for Lifelong Learning, Inc. The City College of New York CCNY/CWE

headline: What's On Today
summary: 9 P.M. (ABC Family) HUGE Becca (Raven Goodwin, above left, with Nikki Blonsky) tries to start a club at camp for a live-action role-play game, but it doesn't catch on until Will (Ms. Blonsky) persuades the other campers to participate. Meanwhile Dr. Rand (Gina Torres) must confront professional and personal problems. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Zahi Hawass, the secretary general of Egypt's Supreme Council of Antiquities, is a guest, and Willie Geist is a guest co-host.

headline: Verizon Open to Rival Apps, Too
summary: Being open doesn't mean being ordinary, at least according to Lowell C. McAdam, the chief executive of Verizon Wireless. Verizon announced on Tuesday a partnership with Google to develop phones with the Android operating system for its network. In a conference call, Mr. McAdam, above right with Eric Schmidt, head of Google, endorsed the openness of Android and said Verizon would support Android applications, like Google Voice, that competed with its own services.

headline: A Cellphone Built for Social Networks
summary: The Motorola Cliq is a provocative smartphone, and that's the best thing about it. A majority of the public will pick it up, look at its ever-changing, multilayered home screen and drop it quickly, alienated and confused.

headline: Vibrations and Music (as You Like) to Shake You Awake
summary: Wake up, wake up, you sleepy head. Can't get out of bed? A new iPhone-compatible product from iLuv, the company that made a name for itself with iPod accessories, will surely get you up and going, if you don't tumble on the floor first.

headline: For Start-Ups, Late Bursts of Private Cash
summary: A FEW years ago, Facebook, which brought social networking to college students and grandparents alike, was expected to be a public company by now. Founded in 2004, it is cash-flow positive and is expected to bring in $1 billion in revenue this year. Yet it is stubbornly staying private and has turned to a new kind of investor for the money that otherwise might have come from a public offering.

headline: German Women Cast Off a Taboo on the Way to Work
summary: Manuela Maier was branded a bad mother. A Rabenmutter, or raven mother, after the bird that pushes chicks out of the nest. She was ostracized by other mothers, berated by neighbors and family and screamed at in a local store. Her crime? Signing up her 9-year-old son Florian when the primary school first offered lunch and afternoon classes last autumn -- and returning to work.

headline: Time Warner Cable and Disney Are Near a Deal on Fees
summary: LOS ANGELES - It looks as though Time Warner Cable customers won't lose ESPN after all.The Walt Disney Company and Time Warner Cable, which have been engaged in heated negotiations over a new distribution contract for Disney-owned television channels, were close enough to a deal on Sunday to remove attack ads aimed at each other.Even so, a final resolution remains days away, emphasized people briefed on the discussions who asked for anonymity because the talks are private. Time Warner Cable's contract with Disney expires Thursday.''The Walt Disney Company and Time Warner Cable have made significant progress in our negotiations for continued distribution of ABC, Disney and ESPN networks and services,'' a joint statement released late Saturday read. ''We are now focusing all our attention on a successful conclusion of these efforts.'' Pressure has been mounting on both companies for months, with each aggressively asking viewers to pick a side - theirs - in television, newspaper and Web ads. Disney is seeking to pry undisclosed fee increases out of a reluctant Time Warner Cable.In a full-page ad that ran in The New York Times on Sunday, for instance, Time Warner Cable warned, ''While we've been working hard to reach an agreement, Disney has been threatening a blackout - and telling Time Warner Cable customers to switch TV service providers.'' (The detente came too late for Time Warner Cable to withdraw the ad.) Disney had been warning viewers that they could lose access to Oprah Winfrey's farewell season and college football games.Indications emerged last week that tensions between the companies were easing. On a Time Warner Cable blog last Wednesday, a spokesman, Jeff Simmermon, wrote of the Disney negotiators, ''I run into those guys in the hallway, in the bathroom, at the coffee machine - and they don't look like they're having any more fun than our people.''A smaller fee fight is also under way at AT&T, which is negotiating a new contract with Crown Media Holdings, parent company of the Hallmark Channel. Last week, the companies warned that Hallmark would be dropped at the end of the month from AT&T's U-verse service, which has about 2.3 million subscribers.Hallmark's president, Bill Abbott, said Thursday that AT&T was ''insisting on unreasonable rates that would seriously jeopardize our longevity.'' AT&T said it was ''making every effort to reach a fair agreement.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL: IDOL GIVES BACK 2010 Alicia Keys, Carrie Underwood, the Black Eyed Peas, Annie Lennox, Jeff Beck and Elton John, as well as a few celebrities not yet revealed, use their star wattage to raise awareness and money for charities around the globe. The special, now in its third installment, has raised more than $140 million to date; this year's show is dedicated to programs like Feeding America, Malaria No More, the American branch of Save the Children and the United Nations Foundation. (Above, LaKisha Jones, left, a Season 6 ''Idol'' finalist, and Stacy Laster of the Houston Food Bank.) Ryan Seacrest will host from the ''American Idol'' stage in Los Angeles. Queen Latifah will hold court at the Pasadena Civic Auditorium. 8 P.M. (13) THROUGH A DOG'S EYES For thousands of disabled Americans, dogs really are man's best friend. In this documentary, Jennifer Arnold, the founder of Canine Assistants, one of the nation's largest service-dog organizations, takes viewers through the process of being matched with, and becoming acclimated to, a dog, while inspirational stories show the transformation of seemingly ordinary dogs into full-blown heroes. Neil Patrick Harris narrates.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROBERTSON, JOSEPHINE T.
summary: ROBERTSON--Josephine T.,Classroom, Inc. mourns the passing of Josie Robertson, our beloved colleague and friend. Josie served with great distinction on our Board with particular interests in the students we serve and gathering other like-minded individuals to our work. She was a generous supporter and brought intelligence, grace, wit and wisdom to our meetings. We will miss her greatly. We extend our deepest condolences to Julian and all of her family. Lewis Bernard, Chairman Jane Canner, President

headline: A Docking Station From iLuv Offers a Nod to the Past
summary: In my recent article about iHome, the largest manufacturer of iPhone/iPod speaker docks, I pointed out that Apple's strict design regulations make it easier for accessories makers to create products, secure in the knowledge that they won't quickly need to reposition one feature or another in response to an Apple design change. That standardization has allowed a large number of iPod accessory manufacturers to flourish, including iLuv.

headline: Google Takes Step To Placate China
summary: SAN FRANCISCO -- Google plans to stop automatically sending users in mainland Chinese to its uncensored Hong Kong site, in an effort to appease Beijing as it seeks to renew its license to operate in China. The action, experts on China say, amounts to a symbolic gesture that Google hopes will placate the Chinese government, which may be feeling pressure from citizens who are demanding continued access to Google's search engine.

headline: A Pocket Camera for When the Lights Are Dim
summary: If you snap a lot of photos in low-lighting conditions, you probably know that point-and-shoot cameras deliver pretty poor image quality once the sun goes down. Of course, you can use flash to get crisper photos, but that kills the ambience of soft natural lighting. Canon addresses this conundrum with its $350 PowerShot SD4000 IS, a newcomer to its ELPH line that delivers low-light images without the whitening blaze of flash.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RAGSDALE, DUANE
summary: RAGSDALE--Duane William, who was Vice Chairman of Ted Bates Worldwide, Inc. when it was the second largest advertising agency in the world, died of Alzheimer's Disease November 17th. He was 85 years of age. Mr. Ragsdale was a resident of New York City for 58 years and spent summers in Mattapoisett, MA for 47 years. Known as Rags, he was born in Baker City, Oregon and attended schools there. During World War II, he attended the University of Colorado in the Naval V12 program and upon graduation he served on the William B. Langfitt troop transport in the Pacific. After the service he attended the Harvard Business School on an academic scholarship and graduated in 1951. Rags' first venture into advertising was in the advertising department of Paramount Pictures in 1951 researching the impact - if any - that the newly developed television might have upon the movie industry. He went on to Compton Advertising, now Satchi & Satchi, where he helped to launch Gleem Toothpaste "for people who can't brush after every meal". His next position was at William Esty. Once at Ted Bates Worldwide, Rags was instrumental in bringing William Esty into the Ted Bates Worldwide Organization. He is a past member of the new York Athletic Club, The Harvard Club of New York, and the American Advertising Federation. He was appreciated for giving full credit to those who worked with him for their contributions to advertising campaigns. He was also known for a wonderful sense of humor. His coworkers refer to the period of time that they worked with him as their "Camelot". He is survived by Mimi his loving wife for 57 years and dear daughter Martha, his niece Dana and nephews Richard and Norman. He was preceded in death by his brothers Lee, Norman and Orville. Rags will be deeply missed by all who knew him. A memorial service will be held at a later date. Please make remembrances to your favorite charity.
