headline: Apple's Struggle On Political Apps
summary: Apple has again changed its mind. Earlier this week, it rejected the iPhone app of a Republican opponent to Representative Henry A. Waxman of California, a Democrat, saying it was a personal attack on Mr. Waxman. But on Tuesday, Apple reversed itself and approved the app.

headline: Strong iPad Sales Abroad Indicate Japan's Decline as Tech Innovator
summary: 7:05 a.m. | Updated With contributions from Tanaya Macheel in Paris TOKYO -- First came ''iPod shock,'' which knocked Japan's favorite gadget - the Walkman from Sony, and its line of successors - off its long-held perch at the top of the tech-savvy wish list. Then came ''iPhone shock,'' which sent Japan's cellphone companies - long used to scoffing at the clunky offerings from their overseas peers - scrambling to develop similar smartphones.

headline: AT&T Faults F.C.C. on Auction
summary: You've got to hand it to AT&T. They don't like Julius Genachowski's plan to apply network neutrality rules to wireless networks, and they aren't shy about saying so. Not so for Verizon and Sprint, which declined to answer a direct question about whether they think wireless systems should be covered by net neutrality rules.

headline: Android Phones Outpace Apple's
summary: By the end of 2011, there could be more smartphones in the United States than the less advanced feature phones, according to a report released Monday by the Nielsen Company, a market trends monitor. The report also notes that the Google Android platform continues to show rapid growth and over the past six months has edged past the Apple iPhone platform with new subscribers.

headline: A Is for Amazon, B Is for Best Buy . . .
summary: Back in the old days, a sign that a corporation had hit the big time was when it got a single-letter stock symbol on the New York Stock Exchange. For example, Ford has ''F,'' AT&T has ''T'' (for telephone) and United States Steel has ''X.'' On the Web, there's another way a single letter can enhance a company's prestige. Go to Google's home page or browser toolbar and type a single letter into the search box. The search engine will then drop down a list of suggestions, based on overall search activity. There are 26 sites that have the distinction of being Google's first suggestion for each letter of the alphabet.

headline: States Weigh Inquiry of Google
summary: Google's headaches over its collection of private data from Wi-Fi networks are intensifying. Attorneys general from about 30 states are investigating whether Google violated any laws when vehicles used by the company to snap pictures for the Street View service also collected snippets of personal information sent over unsecured wireless networks.

headline: Apple Aims to Re-enter Living Room
summary: Knock, Knock. Who's there? Apple TV? Apple TV who? In September 2006, Steven P. Jobs, Apple's chief executive, announced news of the company's latest offering: the Apple TV. Mr. Jobs had high hopes for his latest creation, so high that he told his audience that he hoped the Apple TV would be a fourth leg to the Apple business among PCs and iPods and iPhones. When the Apple TV was unveiled a few months later in early 2007, Mr. Jobs reiterated these comments in an interview with USA Today:We've got two strong legs on our chair today - we have the Mac business, which is a $10 billion business, and music, our iPod and iTunes business, which is $10 billion. We hope the iPhone is the third leg on our chair, and maybe one day Apple TV will be the fourth leg.Yet it wasn't long before Apple downgraded its hopes of a living room accessory and fourth leg to its business, and Mr. Jobs started referring to the poor Apple TV as a ''hobby.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KAY, STANLEY
summary: KAY--Stanley Martin Kaufman. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of the Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. acknowledge with deepest sympathy the passing of Stanley Martin "Kay" Kaufman, our friend and supporter. Condolences are extended to his entire family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc.

headline: Facebook Friends Can Chime In on TripAdvisor
summary: TripAdvisor has introduced a new feature that allows its readers to combine advice from their Facebook friends with the reader reviews that the site is known for. When users arrive at the site, they can click on a Facebook icon to create a TripAdvisor account that links with Facebook. Then, when researching a destination, hotel, attraction or restaurant users will now see a list of their friends who have also been to that location in the top, right-hand corner. In order for friends to show up, though, they also have to be users of the TripAdvisor Cities I've Visited application on Facebook. Then, the TripAdvisor Trip Friends feature allows users to message friends for travel advice.

headline: Doodle Jump at 5 Million Downloads
summary: In early 2009, Igor and Marko Pusenjak, two brothers originally from Croatia, decided they wanted to build an application for the iPhone that would enable them to make extra money on the side. They set out to build a game that included a rabbit jumping up a screen trying to collect carrots. They soon realized that a collection of doodles they had sketched out to test the game were visually fun. And so Doodle Jump was born.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (Animal Planet) VENOM IN VEGAS The adventurer Donald Schultz (''Wild Recon''), above, spends 10 consecutive days with pythons, rattlesnakes, cobras and other deadly roommates in a 16-by-20-foot glass enclosure, outfitted with a bed and tiny bathroom, on the Las Vegas Strip. The danger increases every 24 hours as 5 snakes are added to an original 50 until a count of 100 is reached. What's worse, Mr. Schultz won't know which species he'll be living with until he opens each day's delivery. The purpose of this stunt: to extract venom for pharmaceutical research and perform tests to measure its potency, the depth of fang penetration and the strike range of some of the world's fastest snakes. 8 P.M. (Fox) AMERICAN IDOL The golden ticket winners arrive in Hollywood, where they're met by Ellen DeGeneres at the judges' table.

headline: Seeing That Ad on Every Site? You're Right. It's Tracking You.
summary: The shoes that Julie Matlin recently saw on Zappos.com were kind of cute, or so she thought. But Ms. Matlin wasn't ready to buy and left the site. Then the shoes started to follow her everywhere she went online. An ad for those very shoes showed up on the blog TechCrunch. It popped up again on several other blogs and on Twitpic. It was as if Zappos had unleashed a persistent salesman who wouldn't take no for an answer.

headline: Help in Finding the Most Economical Data Plan
summary: Now that AT&T no longer offers a $30-a-month unlimited data plan, many smartphone owners may wonder how that affects them. For most, it's a chance to save money. But there is no need to guess. There are tools to help people determine their best plan. AT&T basically offers two plans, one allowing up to 200 megabytes of data for $15 a month and the other supplying two gigabytes of data for $25 a month.

headline: Home Security Webcams, Affordable and Simple
summary: In the past, setting up a full-featured Webcam to monitor your home (or your kids and pets) remotely was too confounding for the average user, what with the tweaks needed to network and router settings. Worse, your efforts often yielded blurry, low-resolution video with unreliable availability. Logitech has addressed these issues with a line of new home-monitoring Webcams that are remarkably easy to set up and that deliver high-resolution video for a consumer-level camera.

headline: Fixing an iPhone Flaw, With a Wink
summary: After Apple's iPhone 4 press conference last week, Szymon Weglarski and Jon Dorfman, two designers from Brooklyn, decided they would have a little fun with the iPhone 4's antenna problem. They designed tiny bandages that fit perfectly around the edge of the iPhone, opened a store on the marketplace site Etsy, and named their new product Antenn-aid. Now the two partners are rushing to keep up with orders.

headline: Drawing Social Security
summary: ''Ask an Expert'' is a recurring feature on Bucks where you have the opportunity to question big-brained individuals about a particular area of personal finance or consumer affairs. This week, our attention is on Social Security, specifically, the optimal time to start collecting. Determining that is difficult given the many complicated rules that govern the system. So it's not surprising that ever since we wrote about the topic last summer, readers have not stopped sending us their questions. That's why we've called in Lesley J. Brey, a financial planner with expertise in Social Security, to answer them.

headline: F.B.I. Investigates Breach of AT&T
summary: The Federal Bureau of Investigation said Thursday that it was investigating a security breach on AT&T's Web site that allowed a security group to obtain the e-mail addresses of 114,000 iPad 3G owners. The group also obtained the identification numbers known as ICC-IDs that those iPads use to communicate over AT&T's network.

headline: AT&T Gears Up for a Heavy Load
summary: Buyers of the iPad will grapple with the question of whether spending the extra cash for a model outfitted for wireless data over AT&T's overtaxed network will be worth it. But it's not just tablet computers, which some analysts estimate could sell in the low millions this year, that AT&T has to worry about. In its most recent earnings release, the company said it activated an additional 3.1 million iPhones on its network during the fourth quarter. And at the Consumer Electronics Show in January, AT&T announced plans to begin supporting two Palm smartphones, as well as several Android-powered smartphones, this year -- all of which have the potential to gobble down as much bandwidth as the iPhone.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths HOVEY, GRAHAM
summary: HOVEY--Graham. After a long career of covering world affairs in the United States and abroad for newspapers, wire services and public radio, Graham Hovey joined The New York Times in 1965, serving on its editorial board for more than 12 years, then working in its Washington Bureau as a foreign-policy reporter until September of 1980. Mr. Hovey passed away Saturday, February 20, 2010 in the Luther Crest community in Allentown, PA. He retired from The Times in 1980 to become professor of communications at the University of Michigan and director of Michigan Journalism Fellows, a program that provides an academic year of study and research for journalists at or near mid-career. After his official retirement at 70 in 1986, Hovey remained at Michigan as a professor emeritus to teach a first-year seminar on "The Making of U.S. Foreign Policy." He and his wife, Mary Jean, moved in 1998 to the Luther Crest retirement community in Allentown, PA to be nearer their son, Thomas D. Hovey. Hovey attended what is now the University of Northern Iowa in Cedar Falls, but transferred to the University of Minnesota, where he became assistant city editor of the Minnesota Daily and took his BA in journalism and economics in 1939. After two years as a reporter on the Waterloo Daily Courier in Iowa, he joined the International News Service (INS) bureau in Detroit in 1940 and covered the beginnings of the conversion of Detroit-area industries for war production. Hovey became a full-time sports writer for INS in Chicago in October, 1941. He was covering an intra-city football game in Comiskey Park between the Bears and the Cardinals when he learned of the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, December 7, 1941. This effectively ended Hovey's sports-writing career for he moved to the INS cable desk in New York in March, 1942, and sailed for Africa in May as an INS war correspondent. Hovey left INS late in 1944 to become a foreign-affairs reporter for the Associated Press in Washington. Two years later he joined the New Republic as an assistant editor. But in 1947 he changed course to pursue an MA in political science and history and teach journalism at the University of Minnesota. He moved in 1949 to the University of Wisconsin, where he rose to the rank of associate professor. He also broadcast a weekly program called "The Background of the News" over the university radio station WHA and nine affiliated stations of the Wisconsin State Broadcasting Service. In 1953, Hovey took leave from Wisconsin to accept a two-year Fulbright grant to Italy, where he was accredited to Radiotelevisione Italiana and broadcast a weekly "Letter from Italy" for member stations of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters, a forerunner of National Public Radio. He returned to Wisconsin for the 1955-56 academic year, then joined the editorial page staff of the Minneapolis Star and Tribune, since merged as the Star Tribune. But he also covered international crises at the United Nations, winning the Overseas Press Club of America award for "Best American Press Interpretation of Foreign Affairs" and sharing a National Headliners Club award for his U.N. coverage in 1958. He was then sent to London in January, 1959, as the Minneapolis Tribune's first European Correspondent. After nearly seven years of covering NATO, the evolution of the European Common Market and Community and recurring crises with the Soviet Union over Berlin, Hovey accepted an invitation from John B. Oakes to join the editorial board of The New York Times in 1965. He wrote editorial and occasional signed columns on U.S. policies in Europe, Africa and the Americas, and often visited those areas. Hovey was married June 20, 1941, in Waterloo, Iowa, to Mary Jean Landgraf, a graduate of Columbia University's School of Library Science, who worked in libraries in Iowa, New Jersey, Minnesota, Wisconsin and Washington, DC, in addition to serving as her husband's researcher for writing and lectures. She survives along with their son, Thomas D. Hovey, his wife, Barbara A. of Forty Fort, PA; three grandchildren, Attorney Matthew T. Hovey of Pottstown, PA, Carolyn B. Hovey of Forty Fort, David L. Hovey of Forty Fort. Also surviving are two nieces, Marjorie Eger of Indiana and Lois Schmoe of Florida. Services: Private at the convenience of the family. Services by Stephens Funeral Home, Inc. Please share on-line condolences at: www.stephensfuneral.com Contributions: In lieu of flowers, to Landgraf-Hovey Scholarship, University of Northern Iowa Foundation, 205 Commons, Cedar Falls, Iowa 50614 or the Salvation Army, 144 N. 8th St., Allentown, PA 18101.

headline: A New Route Adds Twists To a Thanksgiving Tradition
summary: Three hundred extra steps. Three extra turns. Two new avenues. The giant balloons will follow a longer route that for the first time bypasses Broadway as they are led downtown on Thursday morning in the Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade.

headline: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.
summary: COOKBOOK TROVE Goes to N.Y.U.

headline: Charging a Phone, Starving the Vampire
summary: Most people know that power chargers for electronic devices draw electricity when plugged into the wall even when they aren't charging something. But short of unplugging every wall wart not in use, what do you do about it? AT&T is introducing a new charger in May called the AT&T Zero that senses when the phone it is charging is unplugged from it and shuts down so that it has no ''vampire draw.'' The price was not announced.

headline: Apple Event Starts a Guessing Game
summary: By now you might have heard: Apple is holding an invite-only news media event on Sept. 1. Invites like these show up two or three times a year, and it's always a puzzle wrapped in a cryptic bow of noninformation. Such is the case with the most recent one, which shows a picture of an Apple-branded guitar.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WILSON, JOHN H.T.
summary: WILSON--John H.T. Classroom, Inc. mourns the passing of John H.T. Wilson, our beloved colleague and friend. John was one of the Founders of Classroom, Inc. and Treasurer of the Board for over 15 years. He was exceptionally generous with both his time and resources and deeply committed to helping the hundreds of thousands of at-risk students we have served since 1991 have the opportunity to achieve success in school. We have greatly benefited from his wisdom, intelligence, energy and enthusiasm. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Sandy and all of his family. Lewis Bernard, Chairman Jane Canner, President

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths WILSON, JOHN H.T
summary: WILSON--John H.T. Classroom, Inc. mourns the passing of John H.T. Wilson, our beloved colleague and friend. John was one of the Founders of Classroom, Inc. and Treasurer of the Board for over 15 years. He was exceptionally generous with both his time and resources and deeply committed to helping the hundreds of thousands of at-risk students we have served since 1991 have the opportunity to achieve success in school. We have greatly benefited from his wisdom, intelligence, energy and enthusiasm. He will be sorely missed. We extend our deepest condolences to Sandy and all of his family. Lewis Bernard, Chairman Jane Canner, President

headline: Facebook Flagged On Privacy Issue
summary: 1:31 p.m. | Updated Included response from Facebook regarding the ACLU's comments about the company's new location feature Moments after Facebook introduced a new feature called Facebook Places on Wednesday that allows its users to share their location and find their friends, advocates raised flags over online privacy.

headline: Reading Sheet Music, IPad Propped on the Piano
summary: I heard a segment on NPR the other day about the George Gershwin classic ''Summertime,'' in which the cultural reporter Sara Fishko noted that the song has been performed in many different summer settings, from the Carolina coast where Gershwin wrote it in the 1930s, to the Woodstock festival in upstate New York where Janis Joplin screeched it out in 1969. But Ms. Fishko really grabbed my attention when she mentioned the somewhat remarkable fact that the song's melody consists of only six notes. (Bonus: It's written in the key of A minor, which means no sharps or flats.) As a not-so-talented pianist, this was too tempting to pass up. So in the spirit of summertime, I purchased the sheet music from Musicnotes.com and printed it on my laser printer. When downloading the sheet music, I noticed a tag that said, ''iPad compatible.''

headline: Pinch and Zoom Comes To the Apple Desktop
summary: In the years I've been using computers, monitors have grown thinner and more vivid in their picture displays, and the technology that runs them has grown faster and less expensive. But two things have remained relatively constant: my keyboard and mouse. Yet that's about to change. I'm pretty certain I will never own a traditional mouse again, at least when I use an Apple computer. Instead I will own a trackpad -- a Magic Trackpad.

headline: Showing iPad Photos Face to Face. How Quaint.
summary: I bought an iPad from Apple last week - Wi-Fi-only, the cheapest model, for $499. And it's awesome. This year's ''it'' gadget has many talents, and chief among them is its ability to share photos, face to face rather than online. Just like the old days when they had those photos printed on paper. The iPad's 9.7-inch LED screen displays images in gorgeous, vibrant color in your choice of horizontal or vertical orientation. As with most things ''i,'' you add photos to the iPad by synching with your iTunes library. You can do so using iPhoto 4.0.3 (or later) or Aperture 3.0.2 (or later) on a Mac; Windows fans can use Adobe Photoshop Elements 3.0 (or later).

headline: The Zeal Of a Convert To Twitter
summary: Two years ago, Buzz Bissinger took a stand against digital culture. A specialist in long-form magazine journalism and the author of ''Friday Night Lights,'' considered by some to be the best sports book ever written, Mr. Bissinger went on HBO's ''Costas Now'' to launch a full-throated assault against online discourse, describing his ''abiding hatred'' for its sarcasm and venom.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths KAY, STANLEY MARTIN KAUFMAN
summary: KAY--Stanley Martin Kaufman. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of the Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. acknowledge with deepest sympathy the passing of Stanley Martin "Kay" Kaufman, our friend and supporter. Condolences are extended to his entire family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc.

headline: How the Destinies of Motorola and Palm Grew Apart
summary: For much of this decade, the fates of Palm and Motorola were intertwined. Both were early innovators in the mobile phone industry, but neither had had a hit in years. Motorola, which had invented cellphones and found great success with the Razr, and Palm, which pioneered the hand-held computer category, watched more nimble competitors lure away consumers with flashier, sleeker and more functional smartphones.

headline: An App That Makes Cards With Vivid Fonts
summary: Since the lamented loss of The New Yorker's free electronic cards, you may have had a difficult time finding e-cards of the noncloying variety. Now, for $1.99, you can get a rack's worth on your iPhone. An app called PixyMe lets you add words to a picture, but not with just plain type fonts. On a picture of a cake, your message appears to be written in icing. Or your message can appear to have been scraped on a snowy windshield, or to be sewn on the back of a ballplayer's jersey.

headline: Sugar to Post Local Shopping Deals
summary: Sugar Inc., the blog network for women, updates its readers on the latest in celebrity gossip, fashion, beauty, parenting and cooking. Now it will update them about the best places to go in their towns for discounted services. On Tuesday, Sugar will announce that it has acquired FreshGuide, a start-up that offers daily local shopping deals aimed at women. The terms of the acquisition were not disclosed.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths STEINBRENNER, GEORGE
summary: STEINBRENNER--George. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. mourn the passing of George Steinbrenner, former Board of Director and generous supporter of our organization. We are deeply saddened for the sudden loss of our dear friend. His passing is a loss for the community as well as his family to whom we extend our deepest condolences. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RAUSEN, AARON
summary: RAUSEN--Aaron. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of the Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. acknowledge with deepest sympathy the passing of Dr. Aaron Rausen, a dedicated member of our Board of Directors, caring friend and supporter. We are grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of having him as a member of our family and we extend our deepest condolences to the Rausen family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan, President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths RAUSEN, AARON
summary: RAUSEN--Aaron. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of the Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. acknowledge with deepest sympathy the passing of Dr. Aaron Rausen, a dedicated member of our Board of Directors, caring friend and supporter. We are grateful for the extraordinary opportunity of having him as a member of our family and we extend our deepest condolences to the Rausen family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn, Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan, President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

headline: One Crowd Still Loyal To Goldman
summary: Lots of people are talking about what is happening at Goldman Sachs. This is a column about what is not happening at Goldman. Despite all the bad headlines -- the accusations of fraud, the talk of a big settlement, the risk, however remote, of criminal charges -- there's an inconvenient truth that's been largely ignored: Most of Goldman's big customers are not bolting.

headline: What's On Today
summary: 8 P.M. (ESPN) THE 16TH MAN In 1995, just a year after the overthrow of apartheid and as the new government of Nelson Mandela was seeking to rebuild the nation, South Africa hosted the Rugby World Cup. Despite having only one nonwhite player, the South African Springboks gained the support of the country and, bucking heavy odds, beat the New Zealand All Blacks. Afterward, Mr. Mandela, far left, wearing a Springboks jersey, walked to the center of the pitch and shook hands with the team's captain, François Pienaar, above right -- a gesture seen as a step toward healing a deeply divided nation. Morgan Freeman, who played Mr. Mandela in the 2009 feature ''Invictus,'' produced this film, directed by Clifford Bestall, as part of ESPN's ''30 for 30'' anniversary programming. 10 A.M. (ABC) RACHAEL RAY Rosie O'Donnell takes audience questions.

headline: New Kindle Leaves Rivals Farther Back
summary: Too bad there's not a reality TV show called ''America's Most Freaked-Out Tech-Company Meetings,'' where you watch classic panicked board meetings. For example, when the Apple employee left an iPhone 4 prototype in a bar. Or when Intel learned that its Pentium chip contained a math error. Or when Microsoft was caught bribing bloggers with $2,500 laptops to promote Windows Vista. One of the most exciting episodes, though, could have been shot at Amazon the day Apple announced the iPad.

headline: In an Era of Cheap Photography, the Professional Eye Is Faltering
summary: By the time Matt Eich entered photojournalism school in 2004, the magazine and newspaper business was already declining. But Mr. Eich had been shooting photographs since he was a child, and when he married and had a baby during college, he stuck with photography as a career.

headline: City Critic: The Future of Mass Transit?
summary: A six-month M.T.A. trial allows riders to use credit cards with PayPass logos to “tap” their way onto trains and buses.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths BENNETT, JACK FRANKLIN
summary: BENNETT--Jack Franklin, of John's Island, Vero Beach, Florida, died peacefully in Greenwich, Connecticut on April 25, 2010 after a year-long battle with cancer. He had lived in Greenwich on and off for nearly 50 years before moving to Florida. He also maintained a summer residence in York, Maine. Mr. Bennett was born in Macon, Georgia on January 17, 1924 to Andrew Jackson Bennett and Mary Eloise Franklin Bennett. He graduated from Yale University in the war-shortened Class of 1945 and served as a U.S Navy Lieutenant (j.g.) on the destroyer U.S.S. Boggs in the Pacific during World War II. He worked in post-war Germany alongside his father who, as Financial Advisor to the U.S. Military Commander of Germany, was the principal administrator of the Deutschemark currency reform that reignited the German economy. On his return from Germany, he earned a Ph.D. in Economics from Harvard University in 1951. Mr. Bennett later moved to Washington, DC where he served in the War Department, the State Department, and the Executive Office of the President, and as the Economist on two Presidential Commissions, including the Fairless Committee on Mutual Security which focused on U.S. - foreign economic policy. In 1955, Mr. Bennett joined the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and worked for its successor Exxon Corporation for over 30 years in New York, London, and Houston. From 1975 to 1989, he was Chief Financial Officer, Senior Vice President and a Director of Exxon. During his tenure at Exxon, the Company became well known for its pioneering use of various financial innovations, including bond defeasance, shelf registrations, sale of Company securities by Dutch auction and large-scale repurchases of company shares. He also served as a Director of the Discount Corporation, the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, Philips Electronics N.V., Dean Witter Mutual Funds and Tandem Computers, Inc. From 1971 to 1975, Mr. Bennett served at the U.S. Treasury in Washington, DC under Secretaries John Connolly, George Schultz and William Simon. He succeeded Paul Volcker as Undersecretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, serving in that role from 1974 to 1975. His work was instrumental to the implementation of the global movement to currency exchange systems based on floating exchange rates and the dismantling of U.S. controls over international capital flows. He also introduced the use of Dutch auctions in the sale of U.S. Treasury securities (still used today). He was awarded the Alexander Hamilton Medal by Secretary Schulz. He was an active Member of the Council on Foreign Relations, a Trustee of the Committee for Economic Development, and a member of the Bilderburg Group for which he also served as Chairman of the U.S. Friends of Bilderberg. He was a member of the University Club (New York, NY), the Stanwich Club (Greenwich, CT), the Blind Brook Club (Purchase, NY), the John's Island Club (Vero Beach, FL) and the York Harbor Reading Room and York Golf and Tennis Club (York, ME). He was predeceased by his wife of 56 years, Shirley Elizabeth Goodwin of Sunderland, Massachusetts. He is survived by three sons and a daughter, and their spouses: Jackson Goodwin (Win) and Rosanah Bennett of Greenwich, Connecticut; Philip D. and Lisa Bennett of London, England; Hugh F. and Kim Bennett of Winchester, Massachusetts; and Fraser Bennett Beede and Robert Beede of Greenwich, Connecticut, as well as by seven grandchildren. He will be remembered for his devotion to his family, his wonderful sense of humor and his innovative approach to business, economic and monetary issues. He loved to play golf and horseshoes with his family and friends. While working on his personal memoirs, he also published in 2009 a book titled Physics Doesn't Need to be That Difficult. Funeral services are private. A memorial reception is planned for a future date.

headline: Final Three for ''Idol''
summary: Ratings for Fox's ''American Idol'' recovered somewhat on Tuesday after falling to an eight-year low last week, but CBS won the night over all by a thin margin. According to Nielsen's estimates, a movie-theme episode of ''Idol,'' with guest-mentoring (and T-shirts) from Jamie Foxx, remained the night's top-rated show, earning 18.7 million viewers at 8 p.m., up from 17.5 million a week ago, but CBS's ''NCIS'' was close behind in the time slot with 16.9 million viewers. The CBS shows ''NCIS: Los Angeles'' (15.9 million) at 9 p.m. and ''The Good Wife'' (12.9 million) at 10 won their time slots as well. ABC placed third on the night and NBC was fourth. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

headline: Editor's Impact Begins With a Capital O
summary: Susan Casey's publishing résumé reflects what one would expect from someone who has chased great white sharks in California, stalked elk in Colorado and tramped the oil-slicked marshlands of Louisiana. Editor of Sports Illustrated Women? Check. Creative director of Outside? Check. Author of a book on sharks and another on extreme surfing? Check, check. Ms. Casey's latest adventure, challenging and dangerous, fits right in: remaking O, the Oprah Magazine with a mandate from none other than the magazine's namesake.

headline: W Takes a New Direction
summary: W, a magazine best known for ethereal photo spreads with dazed-looking models sporting Versace, Chanel, Prada and Ferragamo, is assuming a new look and editorial tone. It is becoming a place that its new editor, Stefano Tonchi, hopes readers will go to not only for high-end fashion but for profiles on cultural figures, travel essays and appraisals of art. The September W contains all of the above, and a healthy dose of pictorial spreads. Some of the elements are provocative: a bare-breasted model donning jewels; blurbs from actresses describing their first on-camera sex scenes (''I will make a sex scene as uncomfortable as I can just to break the ice,'' one says).

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths ROBERTSON, JOSEPHINE
summary: ROBERTSON--Josephine T., Classroom, Inc. mourns the passing of Josie Robertson, our beloved colleague and friend. Josie served with great distinction on our Board with particular interests in the students we serve and gathering other like-minded individuals to our work. She was a generous supporter and brought intelligence, grace, wit and wisdom to our meetings. We will miss her greatly. We extend our deepest condolences to Julian and all of her family. Lewis Bernard, Chairman Jane Canner, President

headline: Voice From Past In a Nike Ad Featuring Woods
summary: Nike, which stood by Tiger Woods when AT&T and Accenture dropped him, began running a new 30-second commercial Wednesday that uses the recorded voice of his father, Earl, who died in 2006. In the commercial, Woods looks at the camera with a dour, unchanging expression as his father's resurrected voice says: ''Tiger, I am more prone to be inquisitive, to promote discussion. I want to find out what your thinking was. I want to find out what your feelings are. And did you learn anything?''

headline: At Bloomberg, A Modest Strategy To Rule The World
summary: PLOPPED in a white leather chair in a small office in Bloomberg L.P's Manhattan headquarters, Andrew Lack knows exactly how to articulate the aspirations of this 28-year-old media and technology company. ''We want to be the world's most influential news organization,'' says Mr. Lack, who oversees Bloomberg's television, radio and dot-com endeavors.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths STEINBRENNER, GEORGE
summary: STEINBRENNER--George. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. mourn the passing of George Steinbrenner, former Board of Director and generous supporter of our organization. We are deeply saddened for the sudden loss of our dear friend. His passing is a loss for the community as well as his family to whom we extend our deepest condolences. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House New York

headline: A Bold Phone Fades a Bit In the Details
summary: Fine print, baby. It's all about the fine print. It'll get you when you buy a car. When you rent an apartment. When you sign a prenup.

headline: 30 SECONDS WITH MICHAEL STRAHAN; Sack Artist Paints A New Picture
summary: N.F.L. training camps are opening, and Michael Strahan says he is happy that he will be in a comfortable television studio. Those wilting two-a-day workouts are one of the few football rituals that Strahan, a former All-Pro defensive end for the Giants, says he does not miss since he retired in 2008. A key member of the team that won Super Bowl XLII, Strahan gets his sports fix now as a co-host of ''Pros vs. Joes'' on Spike TV. The reality show pits amateurs against professionals in various sports. He is also an analyst for ''Fox NFL Sunday.'' Q. Terrell Owens and Donovan McNabb have been feuding since they shared a huddle with the Philadelphia Eagles. In an episode of ''Pros vs. Joes,'' they play on the same team. How did you manage that?A. We didn't know what to expect when they got together. But in the locker room before the show, they were cool. They got there and played well together. The show is so competitive, you put aside all your little issues because you want to win. There were more confrontations with the regular Joes.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CUTTONE, JOSEPH
summary: CUTTONE--Joseph. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of the Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. acknowledge with deepest sympathy the passing of Joseph Cuttone, loving father of our friend and supporter, Donato Cuttone. Condolences are extended to his entire family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House, Inc

headline: What's On Today
summary: 10:30 P.M. (13) PROJECT KASHMIR In this ''Independent Lens'' presentation, Senain Kheshgi, above left, and Geeta V. Patel, right -- one Muslim, the other Hindu, both American -- hide their cameras as they travel to the disputed region of Kashmir to document the costs of war. It is one of the most beautiful places on earth and, with more than 500,000 armed Indian soldiers, one of the most militarized zones. Maggie Gyllenhaal is the host. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY The journalists Laura and Lisa Ling discuss their new book, ''Somewhere Inside: One Sister's Captivity in North Korea and the Other's Fight to Bring Her Home.''

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths CUTTONE, JOSEPH
summary: CUTTONE--Joseph. The Board of Directors, Staff and Volunteers of the Ronald McDonald House of New York, Inc. acknowledge with deepest sympathy the passing of Joseph Cuttone, loving father of our friend and supporter, Donato Cuttone. Condolences are extended to his entire family. Respectfully, Stanley B. Shopkorn Chairman of the Board William T. Sullivan President and Chief Executive Officer Ronald McDonald House, Inc

headline: Cooper-Hewitt Picks Director, First Designer in Job
summary: Bill Moggridge, a founder of the design firm IDEO who is widely credited with designing the look of the first commercial laptop, has been named director of the Smithsonian Institution's Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in New York. Mr. Moggridge, who is to start in March, will be the first design practitioner to run the Cooper-Hewitt, bringing decades of experience as a businessman and industrial designer but none as a museum administrator. He replaces Paul W. Thompson, who left in July after eight years to become the rector, or president, of the Royal College of Art in London. (Caroline Baumann, the museum's deputy director, has been acting director.)

headline: 2010 Could Be the Year of the Tablet
summary: Publishers made 2009 the year of the concept newspaper and concept magazine. Time Inc. teamed up with a design company, the Wonderfactory, to create a concept video of the Sports Illustrated of the future. Then there was another concept video from the Bonnier Group, a Swedish media company, which went a step further and moved the words and images off a screen and onto a table, allowing you to flick, drag and scroll in thin air. Yes, they are beautifully presented, but they are mostly pie-in-the-sky ideas. Until someone actually creates the hardware to run these experiences, the concepts are about as realistic as those in a video about time travel or flying cars.

headline: What's On Sunday
summary: 9 P.M. (Syfy) ALICE (2009) Nick Willing reimagines Lewis Carroll's ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' and ''Through the Looking-Glass'' to tell the story of Alice Hamilton (Caterina Scorsone, above), a modern-day martial arts instructor with commitment issues who -- after turning down a marriage proposal from her love, Jack Chase (Philip Winchester), and an heirloom engagement ring -- finds herself in the madcap Wonderland, a city of twisted towers and casinos built out of playing cards. Kathy Bates plays the Queen of Hearts, the devilish ruler of this parallel universe; Colm Meaney is her King of Hearts. The cast is rounded out by Andrew-Lee Potts, as Hatter; Tim Curry, as Dodo; Matt Frewer, as the White Knight; and Harry Dean Stanton, as Caterpillar. Part 2 will be shown on Monday at 9. 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH GEORGE STEPHANOPOULOSSecretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates discuss President Obama's military strategy for Afghanistan before moving to ''Face the Nation,'' at 10:30 on CBS, and ''Meet the Press,'' at 10:30 on NBC.

headline: A Book Attracts Loads Of Facebook Fans. But Why?
summary: Book authors have been searching eagerly for ways to harness social media to promote their works. So it would seem that Gregory Levey had stumbled upon the magic key after the Facebook fan page of his book went from having just 700 fans to 692,000 in a matter of months - more than New York City (570,000 fans) or the George Clooney fan page (613,000). ''I couldn't believe what I was seeing,'' he wrote in a recent essay on a Web site for authors about the explosion in his book's popularity. ''Who were these people?''

headline: Ben Feder, 86, Hudson Valley Winemaker
summary: Ben Feder, a winemaker whose crisp seyval blancs from Clinton Vineyards helped establish the Hudson Valley as a serious winemaking region, died Sept. 24 at his home in Clinton Corners, N.Y. He was 86. The cause was brain cancer, said his wife, Phyllis.

headline: Cuomo Says 3 Companies Deceived Haitians in New York Seeking Help After Disaster
summary: In his latest salvo against immigration fraud, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Tuesday that he had filed lawsuits accusing several companies of preying on the Haitian population in New York by fraudulently offering immigration services following the earthquake that devastated Port-au-Prince. The lawsuits accuse three companies, all based in Brooklyn, of unlawfully providing legal advice and services to Haitian immigrants even though their owners and employees were not lawyers and were therefore forbidden from representing anyone before immigration authorities, Mr. Cuomo said in a news release (see also Creole version).

headline: Regulators to Parse Google-ITA Deal
summary: Last week, Google announced a deal to acquire ITA, a Boston-area company that makes flight information software. The move will give Google a large foothold in the online travel search market, and control over a critical data source used by many of its competitors, including Kayak.com, Orbitz.com and Microsoft's Bing. But first comes the regulatory review.

headline: New York Kicks
summary: New Yorkers missed out on the basketball superstar LeBron James flaunting his Nikes for the Knicks or Nets when the signed with the Miami Heat last month. However, arm-chair athletes in Manhattan and Brooklyn (the future home of the Nets), the Bronx, Queens and Staten Island can flaunt their own moves in sneakers honoring the five boroughs. Nike's limited-edition Air Force 1 Borough Pack features different colors, logos and laces for each of the city's boroughs. The Manhattan model is a red, silver and white combination, while the Brooklyn edition is black, plum and white.

headline: A Sidewalk Oasis, if You Can Find One
summary: Only two automated public toilets — one in Madison Square Park and one in Corona, Queens — have been installed since the city approved a proposal for 20 of them in 2005.

headline: A Soup Swaps Football Helmets for Hard Hats
summary: The new round of ads will feature men who work in shipyards, quarries and farms who go home to play with their children and help care for them.

headline: Edit to Ali-Frazier Film Brings Protests
summary: The DVD for “Thrilla in Manila” cut five minutes from a fight scene, and some people are questioning the intent.

headline: A Hired Gun for Microsoft, in Pursuit of Google
summary: An engineer who chased after Google for 10 years while at Yahoo is returning to his mission at Microsoft.

headline: ‘Angels in America’ Will Receive Its First New York Revival
summary: As part of its 2010-11 season dedicated to the work of the playwright Tony Kushner, the Signature Theater Company will mount the first New York revival of his “Angels in America” since the Pulitzer Prize- and Tony Award-winning work closed on Broadway in 1994, the troupe’s artistic director said this afternoon.

headline: Misconduct Claimed at U.S. Embassy in Kabul
summary: Accounts say that security has been seriously compromised by mismanagement and misbehavior among guards and their supervisors.

headline: For Profit, Industry Seeks Cancer Drugs
summary: Companies are pouring billions into developing cancer drugs, lured by the high prices such drugs can command.

headline: In a Sale, Skype Wins a Chance to Prosper
summary: The $1.9 billion deal values Skype, the Internet calling service, at $2.75 billion, higher than many analysts had expected.

headline: Rodale and the Obamas Make a Case for Health (and Health Care)
summary: The Obamas make their pitch for health care changes to magazines in the Rodale group.

headline: Customers Angered as iPhones Overload AT&T
summary: The cellular network is straining to meet iPhone users’ demand, resulting in dropped calls and delayed messages.

headline: Pfizer Pays $2.3 Billion to Settle Marketing Case
summary: The government charged that executives throughout the company planned schemes to illegally market Bextra and other drugs.

headline: Moving Mac’s Music
summary: How can I move my current music library, which is on an iMac running Mac OS X 10.3, to a PC that is running Microsoft Windows XP Home Edition?

headline: Tugboat Workers Strike Over Staffing
summary: Tugboat workers went on strike Monday against a small company to protest its proposal to reduce staffing levels.

headline: ‘Anna In-Between’
Reactions to the Jobs Report
summary: The United States economy shed 216,000 jobs in August as the unemployment rate rose to 9.7 percent, according to a report released by the Labor Department on Friday. Here is how economists and other analysts reacted:

headline: ‘The Anthologist’
Pro-Ams Humble Rich While Rewarding the Tour
summary: Pro-ams on the PGA Tour are among the most valuable hours in sports, a chance for the game’s biggest financial supporters to play alongside golf’s biggest stars.

headline: Stimulus Funds Go to Company Under Cloud
summary: Bovis Lend Lease has been awarded $6 million, though it has faced two criminal investigations and has been suspended from working on New York City schools.

headline: Hollywood Players Vie to Tell DeLorean’s Story
summary: The movie industry is eying an epic pileup of projects featuring a somewhat unlikely new film hero: the renegade automotive entrepreneur John Z. DeLorean.

headline: Exhilaration as Giant Mall Springs Up in a Strike Against Blight
summary: The Gateway Center at Bronx Terminal Market may be the maraschino cherry topping a revival of South Bronx neighborhoods that began more than two decades ago.

headline: Missing a Daily Ritual in Michigan
summary: This past week, I visited a place that newspapers forgot, or was it the other way around? While working on an article about Time Inc.'s decision to parachute into Detroit for a year, I tried to get used to the fact that the newspapers there get delivered only three days a week and the other days, it is tough to find them. Too bad, because between a city where stories seem to lie around every corner and with such a really talented bunch of journalists on hand, it would be nice to have a newspaper plop into the middle of things more often. But as Richard Pérez-Peña points out, newspapers are deathly ill, no more so than in a place like Michigan where the implosion of the auto industry has created collateral damage in all sectors of the economy.

headline: Seeking an Entrepreneurial Recharge
summary: I am at the Inc. 500/5000 Conference near Washington. I am told that there are about 1,700 entrepreneurs coming to the conference and awards dinner. Given the state of the economy over the past year, I find that encouraging. I have talked to quite a few people already, and I can tell you that it is a cross-section of small business, inside and outside of the United States. Sure, some of the people here are expanding their businesses at a tremendous rate and are going to get an award on Friday night. At the same time, many others have felt the pressure of the bad economy and have seen their sales go down. The common denominator is that everyone is looking forward to insights and inspiration from not only a distinguished list of speakers but from one another. I plan on sharing some of those insights with you as I make my way through the conference.

headline: Sitcom Survival: Yesterday's Shaky Residents Are Today's Put-Upon Professors
summary: In May the stop-and-start hospital sitcom ''Scrubs'' had what sure looked like its final episode: parade of past characters, teary walk-off, blooper reel, production shots of the lead actors doing their ''series wraps.'' A few weeks later the show got a last-minute reprieve: it was renewed for a ninth season, which begins Tuesday night on ABC with two new episodes. It's still called ''Scrubs'' despite the protests of its creator, Bill Lawrence, who wanted a new title to indicate how drastically he was changing the show. As ''House'' has done over the last season and a half, ''Scrubs'' is significantly remaking its cast, though on a much tighter schedule: scene to scene, you can watch the new show emerging from the old.

Green Inc. spoke with Mr. Renner yesterday.

headline: Harley-Davidson Recalling 111,000 Motorcycles

The company told the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that it discovered the problem during its own crash testing, and it is not aware of any "fires, injuries or fatalities" related to the defect. The recall covers 2009-10 Touring, CVO and Trike motorcycles.

headline: Neighbors Protest That a New Shelter Is One Too Many
summary: When a developer built an upscale apartment building in the Westchester Square area of the north Bronx, complete with balconies and plans for a day care center, neighbors took it as a sign that their scruffy community was on the rise. But now, a year later, the six-story brick building has been converted into a homeless shelter for more than three dozen families. Instead of a cause for hope, local leaders see the building, at 1564 St. Peter's Avenue, as an emblem of the neighborhood's problems, and a fresh source of kindling for their anger at City Hall.

headline: Google Appears Closer to Releasing Its Own Phone
summary: In recent months, tech blogs have been abuzz with rumors that Google is planning to market its own smartphone based on its Android operating system. The plan would signal a more aggressive effort by Google, which so far has relied on partners to build and market Android phones, to become a force in mobile devices. It could also put Google at odds with those partners, which include Verizon Wireless and Motorola, and it would sharpen its competition with Apple, whose iPhone dominates the high-end smartphone market in the United States.

headline: Suit Accuses Citigroup Of Fraud In EMI Deal
summary: Terra Firma, the British private equity firm, sued Citigroup on Friday, accusing the bank of fraud in its handling of the 2007 sale of the music publisher EMI. In its complaint, filed in New York State Supreme Court, Terra Firma says that it was essentially tricked into paying £4 billion, or $6.5 billion, for EMI in May 2007, near the height of the private equity boom. The private equity firm and its chairman, Guy Hands, have since been criticized for paying too high a price for the music publisher only months before the credit markets began to implode.

headline: Temptations
summary: You may be tempted this season to give in to the plea from that persistent sales clerk at one of the big retailers -- ''Are you sure you don't want to save 15 percent today?'' -- and open up a couple of store-brand credit cards. After all, a 15 percent discount, or no interest payments for 18 months, sounds enticing when you are buying gifts by the armful. But before you start filling out the application, there are some things you need to know. If you carry a balance on store-brand cards, known in the industry as private-label cards, or if you miss a payment on your no-interest purchase, you can end up wiping out those initial savings, and then some. And when you open a new credit card, your credit score can suffer, too.

Ms. McLaughlin -- who has written five books with Ms. Kraus, went to college with her and suffered the indignities of caring for wealthier-than-thou children alongside her -- ordered the same dish.

headline: Emerald Bowl: Boston College (8-4) vs. No. 24 Southern California (8-4)
summary: As Boston College rose, Southern California fell. The two teams meet somewhere in the middle, with the Eagles happy to exceed preseason expectations and the Trojans licking their wounds far, far away from the program's typical perch atop the Pac-10. The rationale behind Boston College's lack of preseason hype was simple: Jeff Jagodzinski was gone, let go following the season and replaced by the longtime B.C. assistant Frank Spaziani; the all-American linebacker Mark Herzlich, diagnosed with cancer, sat out the season; and the projected starting quarterback, academically ineligible, transferred. Despite the travails, B.C. has extended its streak of eight-win seasons to nine, with the potential for a sixth straight nine-win campaign with a victory Saturday. What about those Trojans? Yeah, eight wins for the Eagles is par for the course, if not in 2009 an outright success -- not so much for U.S.C.

headline: Why There's Ammonia in Your Hamburger
summary: What's the secret ingredient in hamburgers sold at McDonald's, Burger King and your children's school cafeteria, in perhaps most of the hamburgers sold in this country? Ammonia. No, this isn't the latest import scare from China. For the past few years, burger makers have been saving money by using filler from Beef Products Inc. consisting of fatty meat scraps often more contaminated than regular meat, to which ammonia has been added to kill the pathogens. The scraps had previously been used only in pet food and cooking oil. But E. coli and salmonella have still been found in this filler. You may not have known any of this, but the federal government did. Read Michael Moss's investigation, just not while you're eating.

However, whatever points the Cowboys have lost on offense has been made up for by a shockingly aggressive, opportunistic defense. Yes, you read that right: Oklahoma State can play some defense. O.S.U. will be tested by the Rebels, whose team speed rivals anything the Cowboys have seen this season.

What remains is a rematch of last season's Poinsettia Bowl, which saw the Horned Frogs outlast the Broncos by a single point. headline: Lehman Hid Money With Help of Global Rules
summary: Lehman Brothers' now notorious Repo 105 scheme depended on forum shopping, Reuters Breakingviews says. The investment bank wasn't able to persuade its lawyers in the United States that the relevant repurchase agreements constituted real sales. So it routed them through its British subsidiary. That meant they came under the British legal system, and the law firm Linklaters was able to opine that the transactions counted as sales.

headline: Sampler: Pacific Gas and Electric Rates Might Hurt Solar, and Cats Prowl Amid Evidence
summary: New Rates Could Slow Adoption of Solar | The proposed rate structure announced last week by Pacific Gas and Electric would replace the current five tiers with three. Most customers' bills would rise, but those using the most electricity would see significant reductions, to about 30 cents per kilowatt hour from the current level of nearly 50 cents. The existing rates have been a boon to California's residential solar industry, but these incentives would be reduced under the new plan. P.G.&E. has asked state regulators to rule on the proposal by year's end. If approved, the rates would go into effect in May 2011. David Hochschild, a vice president for external relations at Solaria, a solar manufacturer in Fremont, said, "You can't have one foot on the gas and one foot on the brake at the same time." [The San Jose Mercury News]

The Senate is expected to take a key procedural vote on the bill by Monday evening.

headline: A Good Bad Week for Catholicism
summary: Last Wednesday, the Vatican formally accepted the resignation of Bishop James Moriarty, the third Irish prelate to step down over his role in sex abuse cover-ups. The next day, a German bishop, Walter Mixa of Augsburg, offered his resignation over allegations that he'd been involved in physical abuse at an orphanage in the 1970s and '80s. Then on Friday it was Belgium's turn: The bishop of Brugges resigned after publicly admitting to having sexually abused a minor two decades ago. And over the weekend, Sweden's lone Catholic bishop announced his willingness to resign over a woman's claim that he'd failed to respond to an allegation of sex abuse against one of his diocese's priests.

headline: Now Showing | Roy McMakin
summary: The exhibition "Roy McMakin: When is a chair not a chair?" opened on Tuesday at Cristina Grajales Inc. in SoHo, to coincide with the publication of a monograph with the same title published by Skira Rizzoli.  McMakin, an artist and designer whose work has been featured in T and The New York Times Magazine, is known for his embrace of ambiguity and subversive humor in the design of seemingly mundane objects: A chest of drawers, for instance, that has no drawers; a teapot with the vestiges of a broken handle; a headboard that takes a "pretty" 1940s-inspired design and deconstructs it. While McMakin designs perfectly functional interior and furniture, he does it with an artist's eye, eschewing conventional ideas of perfection or comfort. The exhibition runs until July 2.
